SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, will be absent from Question Time today due to illness. TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recall receiving a letter dated 6 November 1987 from the National President of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA), Ms Ann Forward, expressing concern about aspects of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs? Did that letter claim improper recruitment procedures; appointment of persons not competent to perform the duties they have allegedly been recruited to perform; widespread administrative malpractice; alarming loss of morale; misuse of travelling allowance; and payments for consultants who have not delivered an identifiable service? Did the National President ask for a `thorough internal but independent investigation before loyalties are stretched too far and a wider more public investigation becomes necessary'? What specific steps did the Minister take to investigate the allegations when they were first raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do recall getting a letter from the National President of the ACOA. I responded in writing for her to elaborate on her accusations. I subsequently met with Ms Forward and no details were presented. When one gets a letter of that sort, one naturally becomes very concerned by the accusations. I have made extensive inquiries within the Department. The matter was addressed by Mr Miller in his responses to Senate Estimates Committee E. No evidence has yet been produced in respect of any of the accusations that she makes. It is extremely difficult for me, in the position I hold, when I get a letter in which a series of allegations are made and no proof at all is produced. Anybody can write such a letter, but if people are not prepared either publicly or confidentially to explain to me the substance of their allegations it makes my job very difficult. If, on the other hand, evidence is presented to me-I will elaborate a little on this point-concerning any of the allegations made or any of the loose talk that is currently flowing through the corridors of this building, I will act upon it. I give that commitment to the House yet again.

ANSWER.PARA: I also take the opportunity to say to members of the Opposition that if they have any confidential information regarding the type of issue raised in that letter and others, I challenge them to bring it to me. I guarantee them a quick response. If action needs to be taken, I will take it. Accusations such as those which have been made in recent days are a slur, unfortunately, on all Aboriginal organisations, on all employees in the four areas under my portfolio, being my Department, the Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I believe that it is simply not good enough to make wide ranging statements hoping that something will develop or something will come forward. I make a plea to the honourable member, as I know of his very keen interest in this area. Every step was taken to look at the issues raised by Ann Forward. I have done that, but in the absence of concrete information it is extremely difficult. If honourable members have information on these issues, I ask them to bring it forward. I give them my commitment that I will follow it through. I can do no more than that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL PRACTITIONERS: PROPOSED NEW FEE STRUCTURE

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Community Services and Health to recent polls showing that the majority of general practitioners (GPs) do not intend to adopt the new fee structure proposed by the Australian Medical Association (AMA). I ask whether the Minister can inform me and the House what action he now proposes to take to ensure that patients continue to receive high quality primary medical care.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question and for her continuing interest in the well-being of health care consumers. Naturally, I welcome the evidence that the great bulk of general practitioners in this country have decided to reject the AMA's proposed new fee structure and to charge according to the Medicare schedule. Even the Federal President of the AMA acknowledged this morning in the Age that only a minority of doctors were expected to charge their patients according to the new schedule. Let me make it clear that I do not regard this as a victory for the Government. I regard it above all as a victory for the patients. I think it is also a rejection of the confrontationist approach of the AMA to this issue. It is a rejection of the Association's attempt to impose a new charging system, a new structure, on both doctors and patients.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not surprised that the great majority of GPs appear to have rejected the proposals that the AMA has made because general practitioners have consistently shown themselves to be fair, caring and responsible people, and have observed in very great numbers the schedule fee over the past five years. Indeed, only 3 per cent of GP standard consultations in the last year were charged according to the AMA's recommended fee levels. The indications are clear that the GPs are not prepared to inflict financial hardship on their patients in order to increase their own incomes.

The Government, for its part, makes it quite clear that it is prepared to respond to this responsible attitude of GPs by showing and announcing its willingness to work with any medical organisation which is prepared to adopt a cooperative rather than a confrontationist approach to resolving any real concerns that the GPs have. The Government is happy to discuss constructively changes to the Medicare benefit schedule, the overriding purpose of which would be to improve the standard of patient care. I am hopeful that consultations later today will result in a much more constructive approach by the AMA.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Minister's media release of 31 October in which he announced that the Commonwealth Auditor-General would undertake an audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and that an officer of the Department of Finance would work with the Commission on finance matters. In view of the serious allegations which have been made about mismanagement within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, why has the Minister excluded his Department from the audit? What other investigations have been initiated into management of the Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps in the discussion of the honourable member's matter of public importance later in the day we can elaborate on this matter a little more, and I look forward to it. The honourable member's question is a valid one. Senator Walsh has written back to me and has suggested that some assistance could be given to the Department. The accusations were made at the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee E. I think the honourable member will find, on an examination of what occurred in the Friday, Tuesday and Wednesday discussions, that most of the more serious accusations-a lot of them unfounded, of course-were made in regard to the ADC.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat again my statement of yesterday and of a number of times prior to yesterday-also the Prime Minister's statement of last night and my statement of this morning: if there is any malpractice, misappropriation of funds or irregularities in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs of which the honourable member is aware, I will act immediately. If the honourable member wishes to question whether I will do that, he should supply the information and let me prove how swiftly I will move if there is proof of such things occurring. That is all I say. There will be Finance Department assistance to the Department. But the serious nature of the accusations that have been made, not only about the ADC but also about people involved in the workings of the ADC-general, broad, sweeping statements, encompassing a lot of very good people, I might add-requires that an independent body such as the Office of the Auditor-General come in and once and for all settle whether anything is wrong. That is surely what the Opposition wants me to do; it is surely what the public wants me to do. And, I will tell you what, it is what the Aboriginal people want me to do, too.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BRUCE STADIUM, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: RUGBY LEAGUE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Territories. What was the reason for the Government's decision to change the excellent sporting facilities at Bruce Stadium to accommodate rugby league? Also, why did the Government accommodate an unnecessary move by the Canberra-Queanbeyan Raiders from Queanbeyan to Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supporter of Australian rules football, I thank the honourable gentleman for his question and can answer with complete objectivity. The Canberra Raiders are not being forced to move. They feel that in order to maintain themselves in the Sydney league competition they have to increase greatly gate receipts. They are therefore aiming to improve significantly home ground attendances. While the New South Wales Government offered to upgrade their existing oval in Queanbeyan, the club was concerned that access and parking difficulties would limit crowd numbers. Accordingly, the club was concerned to move to Bruce Stadium in order to enhance its ability to attract major sponsorship. The Australian Institute of Sport has agreed to lease the stadium to the Australian Capital Territory Administration, which will in turn make it available for the Raiders. The Raiders will be charged commercial rates for the use of the facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: The redeveloped Bruce Stadium will be suitable for a range of other uses, including rugby union, Australian rules, soccer and cricket; and it is hoped to provide a first-class venue for both players and spectators. The athletics community, and the Australian Institute of Sport athletes in particular, will also have a high-class facility, at what is now the adjacent warm-up track, suitable for a whole range of athletic endeavours. It is intended that the stadium be managed by a trust which will include representatives of the ACT Administration, the Institute of Sport and the community. I can understand the honourable gentleman's concern and I understand that some of his constituents in Queanbeyan feel a bit upset about having to drive all the way over to the stadium. But, if I might give him some words of comfort as the member of Melbourne Ports: we once housed the South Melbourne football team-and when it plays it is a hell of a drive!

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his statement on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning that `there will be no cover-up' regarding inquiries into the Aboriginal Development Commission. Does the Prime Minister recollect that on 22 May 1985 a report on the Aboriginal Development Commission was tabled in this House by the then Chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, Mr Leo McLeay, and that that report contained a minority report supported by seven members of that Committee which recommended a judicial inquiry into allegations made under oath to that Committee and about which a leading Queen's Counsel, Mr Coombs, had recommended referral to the Australian Federal Police? I ask the Prime Minister: Why did his Government cover up these allegations? In the light of his Minister's just made statement that he will act on firm evidence, will the Prime Minister now reopen that inquiry as a judicial inquiry?

—There was no cover-up. I endorse completely what the Minister has said in his thorough answer to the House on this matter. In the light of the answer that the Minister has given, I will refer the honourable member's question to him and ask him whether, in the light of any subsequent developments, he feels that there is any need to refer to the matters of the report of 22 May 1985.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether his attention has been drawn to an article in the Business Review Weekly of 14 October reporting on a study undertaken by a group of Melbourne-based occupational health and safety consultants which found that inadequate attention is paid by senior management in Australian companies to health and safety practices and that this often contributes to a sharp rise in workers compensation claims. If so, can the Minister explain what the Government is doing to redress occupational injury and disease in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He raises an issue of considerable importance to Australian industry and our economy generally. I think it is worth noting that each year some 550 Australians die as a result of work-related accidents or illness and over 300 of those deaths occur at the workplace. A conservative estimate of the cost of that loss of life and the injuries and illness involved is about $6,000m per annum. The cost of workers compensation alone runs to about $3,000m per annum. I should take the time of the House to compare that with the performance of our trading partners. In Australia we have a fatal injury rate at work of about 77 deaths per million workers. That compares with a rate in Sweden of 22; Japan some 20; and the United States of America some 37.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked what this Government is doing about this. In 1985 we established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. That Commission has a specific national charter-a charter to establish a uniform national approach to dealing with this major problem. It has before it the task of developing uniform standards; providing better education, training and research; focusing on priority issues; and collecting accurate statistical data. All that is being done on a tripartite basis. Again, it is a case of the trade union movement, industry and government working together to reduce the level of casualties and to reduce the costs that are involved.

I can say that already codes of practice have been developed for the safe handling of asbestos and timber preservatives and in respect of repetition strain injury. Further work is being done on six specific issues: occupational back pain, noise-induced hearing loss; skin disorders; occupational cancer; mechanical equipment injury; and chemicals in the workplace. I repeat that this is the first time the issue raised by the honourable member has been addressed on a national basis. Overall, it is a fundamental part of the Government's strategy of generating secure, satisfying and safe jobs. It is part of the overall Government package to create a more efficient, more productive and more competitive Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs again to the letter he received from the President of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA), Ms Ann Forward, in which he will recall she raised the matter of widespread patronage and malpractice in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Given that Ms Forward indicated that one of the barriers to investigating the administration of Aboriginal affairs was the fact that departmental officers either were compromised or feared reprisal, was his response to her letter, to which he referred in the answer to the first question asked this afternoon, based only on his departmental Secretary's outright rejection of the claim and without any further independent investigation? In the light of Ms Forward's serious accusations and to ensure that there is a totally unprejudiced inquiry into matters now under reference to the Commonwealth Auditor-General, will the Minister ask his Secretary to stand aside until the inquiry is completed?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no; I have no intention of asking Mr Perkins to stand aside. The right honourable member has not yet offered me any reason why I should. In regard to the first part of his question, I repeat that I received a very detailed letter from the President of the ACOA, Ms Ann Forward. I wrote back to her. I discussed the comments made in her letter and asked her to produce any evidence she might have regarding any of those issues. Since that meeting, which was held towards the end of last year, I have had a number of meetings with her. I can report to the House that the discussions with the ACOA are proceeding very well. The matter has not been raised by her with me since, in terms of the accusations made in that letter. When this issue came up in questions in the Senate Estimates Committee last week, I again discussed the matter briefly with Ms Forward. Again, there are no accusations. In her press release she makes the comment that she had good discussions with me. That is where the matter rests. I do not intend to proceed to take the action the right honourable member requests in the latter part of his question.
—Can the Minister for Employment and Education Services inform the House of the Government's program in the area of student income assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I know of the keen interest that she takes in her electorate concerning the schools and the schooling of young Australians in that part of the nation.
—What about the isolated children?

—I think this is a matter which will be of particular interest to the people of Australia, even if it is of no interest to the Opposition, because most people are concerned about the future of young Australians and are very pleased with the way this Government is ensuring that young Australians have much better opportunities through the policies of this Government, which encourage them to stay at school longer. A very important limb of our policies in this area is the policies that we have put in place to ensure that all students can have reasonable income support whilst they are in the secondary system in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the House that when we came into office only 52,000 secondary students throughout the nation were receiving income support from the Government, that is, the previous Fraser-Howard regime. Under this Government, after about 5 1/2 years, 144,000 students throughout the nation are receiving income support. This is a quite remarkable turnaround in anybody's language. There are 200 per cent more students on assistance than was the case under the previous Liberal Government. The result of that has been that we have seen a quite dramatic increase in retention rates in this country. When we again came to office in 1983 school retention rates were a quite disgraceful 36 per cent-a very poor retention rate by international standards. This Government has worked hard at increasing retention rates. This year we have now achieved an estimated 58 per cent retention rate to year 12 throughout the nation. We are well on target to achieve our set goal of 65 per cent in the early 1990s. I believe that we will achieve that. This represents, not only for the individuals concerned but also for the nation, a great leap forward in educational standards. It should ensure that all young Australians are now able to gain a much better opportunity in life than was the case under the previous Liberal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware that donations to mobile life education units are not tax deductable because the Australian Taxation Office has ruled that the 27 mobile life education units operating throughout Australia play a purely educational role and are not providing direct relief from the affliction of drugs? Does the Treasurer accept the value of mobile life education centres in protecting the youth of Australia from substances of addiction? As the Minister Assisting the Treasurer has advised me that an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act will be necessary to provide the concession to the life education centres, will the Treasurer tell the House when he will introduce the appropriate amendment? If he does not intend to do this, will he tell the people of Australia why?

—I was asked this question in the last sitting week when I said that I would look at the matter. I will look at the matter again. My office would have been looking at the issue; so I will dredge it up and get back to the honourable member in the next day or so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Incidentally, I understand that he, like the Prime Minister, has had a win today. The Minister will be aware of widespread concern in the community over illegal fishing activities by Indonesian fishermen and their persistent illegal entry into Australian territorial waters. Obviously, this is a matter of concern to people in Western Australia as well as people in Australia generally. Will the Minister inform the House of the attitude of the Indonesian Government on this matter and what action the Australian Government has taken in regard to it?

—This is a matter the honourable member has indicated concern about. The recent spate of seizures of Indonesian vessels fishing illegally inside the Australian fishing zone, north-east of Darwin particularly, has added a new dimension to the existing problems with poaching off the north-west coast near Broome and breaches over the years of the 1974 memorandum of understanding under which Indonesian traditional fishermen are allowed to fish around Australian islands. Australia's concerns about illegal activity by Indonesian fishermen in Australian waters have been raised with the Indonesian Government on a number of occasions this year. During the recent visit of Senator Gareth Evans to Indonesia in discussions with the Indonesian Foreign Minister it was agreed that the illegal fishing activity was a needless irritant to the relationships between Australia and Indonesia. It was agreed by the two Ministers to explore further ways of cooperating to halt the illegal fishing, including through establishing a mechanism for consultation and cooperative action. It has also been agreed that officials of both countries should discuss more effective implementation of the 1974 memorandum of understanding. Particularly, Indonesia, for its part, will send a team of officials into the areas from which most of the fishermen originate to warn them of the illegality of their fishing activity and, further, the penalties attracted by it. These visits will reinforce the actions of the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, which has publicised the severe penalties for breaches of Australian fisheries and quarantine laws. It is hoped that these steps will alleviate what is becoming a difficult problem.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I note that the Minister and the Prime Minister now realise that there are massive problems associated with the elderly people of Australia. Is the Minister aware that the ideology that the elderly should stay at home as long as humanly possible is supported in the main by most members of this House? Is the Minister also aware that the home care system is inadequate, that there is not enough funding, and that it is completely off the rails-that too many people are living in their own homes and looking for carers who are just not there and are not trained enough to look after them? Will the Minister give an assurance that he will look at this massive problem, recruit more people, and make certain that the elderly are looked after, if he wants them to stay in their own homes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am glad that the honourable member recognises-and I hope that others on the other side of the House also recognise-the importance of the home and community care (HACC) program. I am glad that Opposition members recognise that the home and community care program, which was an initiative of this Government, is playing a very important role in helping the frail aged and the young disabled to remain as long as possible in the community close to their families and the facilities around them.

ANSWER.PARA: Since its inception, the home and community care program has been very successful. Unfortunately, in some States much of the funding that is required has not matched the level of funding that the Commonwealth has been prepared to commit. In that regard the Commonwealth is certainly hoping that more money will be forthcoming from the States, as it is a joint Commonwealth-State program, in order to provide more and better services-in fact, a wider range of services-for the frail aged and the young disabled. In that regard the home and community care program is being assessed under the HACC review, and State, Commonwealth and Territory Ministers are looking at the results as they come through.

The points that the honourable member has raised in some areas have been taken into account. What we are trying to do with the funds available-and again we hope that the States will match the Commonwealth's effort and the various initiatives that are put forward-is to make sure that the States will take up a lot of the responsibilities in service delivery that they have not been able to do in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy seen reported comments of the Policy Director of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) on next year's tax cuts? Can the Minister advise the House of the effect of those proposals on farmers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday the National Farmers Federation Policy Director went on the Country Hour and suggested that the NFF was considering a position that all available money for tax cuts next year be used to reduce the top personal marginal rates, the corporate tax rate, and the fringe benefits tax to 29 per cent, and that the indirect tax system be broadened. Dr Hooke also advocated spending cuts of $9 billion, which in themselves--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. Standing order 142 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected . . .
Although I realise that farmers would come somewhere in his portfolio, the reality is that he is talking about tax. Surely the matter should have been referred to the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.

—Dr Hooke also advocated spending cuts of $9 billion, which in themselves would devastate living standards in rural Australia. What concerns me about this is that the tax proposals would confine the tax cuts to the top half of taxpayers only; not one cent would be provided for low to middle income earners. The effect would be even worse for farmers. Farm incomes, thankfully, have increased this year but, even allowing for that, only 50 per cent of farmers would benefit from a tax cut of this nature. In a poorer year for farm incomes such as last year, only 40 per cent of farmers would benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: I am concerned about such an approach that has little idea of equity and only caters for the wealthier farmers. I reject such a regressive approach. It is inconsistent with other policy goals of the NFF. For example, if one had a tax rate of 29c in the dollar the case for income equalisation deposits (IEDs) would be diminished. I spoke to the NFF President, Mr John Allwright, yesterday on this issue. He told me that the NFF does not have a final position on tax matters, but he in no way retracted the comments made by his organisation's Policy Director.

Honourable members will be aware that in May we announced that tax linked equalisation deposits would be available to farmers next year. This is a major concession to farmers, particularly the wealthiest farmers, as it is in addition to tax averaging. In the light of the comments by the NFF, it would be irresponsible for me to finalise the detailed arrangements for IEDs until the NFF has decided what its real position on tax issues is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Minister's undertaking to the House earlier this afternoon that, if specific allegations were put by Opposition members, they would get a speedy response. Is it a fact that 5 1/2 months ago, on 17 May 1988, the honourable member for Gilmore, accompanied by a senior staff member of Mr Hatton, the Independent member for the South Coast, together with Aboriginal community leaders from the Shoalhaven Shire district, saw the Minister and provided him with detailed complaints about maladministration, even corruption, relating to the Aboriginal Medical Service? Is it a fact that the Minister has not yet replied to the honourable member for Gilmore? In view of the fact that 5 1/2 months have gone by, why not? Further, if he has not replied, why should we now take his assurance seriously?

—It is a fact that I was approached by the honourable member for Gilmore and other persons. That is true. I am a bit surprised that the honourable member for Gilmore wants me to relay all of the details. I will be happy to produce all of the details. Steps have been taken by the New South Wales office of the Department regarding the accusations that he made. Given that he was the one who asked me to keep the names of the people who came to see me confidential, and given that he was the one who came into my office with people and asked that they be protected-the matter is being addressed-I have to say--
—Order! There is far too much noise. The House is interested in the Minister's reply.

—A series of accusations were made. If I remember, one was about groceries. We have investigated the groceries matter and other actions. People come into my office, as the honourable member for Gilmore did, and make a plea, prior to introducing other people, that under no circumstances are those people to be in any way implicated in the claims that they make.
—That is not the issue.
—Just a moment. I can assure the honourable member that the accusations and other matters are being well and truly addressed.
—Order! Honourable members on my left might listen to the Minister's answer. The Leader of the Opposition has asked a serious question and the Minister is replying.

—I can assure the honourable member that the accusations are being well and truly addressed, as well as other matters that have arisen following investigation into the claims that were made in my room when I met with the honourable member and those people. I can assure the honourable member that the matters he raised are being looked at. But subsequent to those matters being raised, other matters emerged. I am quite happy to give him a full up-to-date report-
—You have not responded yet.

—Just a minute. The matters that were raised with me I think have been addressed. Other matters have arisen. It is extremely difficult when people come in and say they do not want to be named and then make charges; I give those people the protection that I am asked to--
—All you have to do is respond.
—All I have to do is trust the honourable member? God help us. People come in and ask to be protected and the honourable member gets up in here and brings the matter before the Parliament.
—We haven't named anybody.

—Well, it will not take the network long to know who they are. I always respect a request when people come to my office and seek an appointment and make the plea, by the way, that one of my staff members should not be present in the office while those people come in, in case word was to filter back. That is the sort of situation we had in my office when the honourable member came in. I agreed with that. I have followed the honourable member's complaints, and if he wants to talk to me about what has happened, I am happy to do that. The fact is that the Opposition asked for the matter to be kept extremely confidential to protect people who were laying charges. I have acted on those accusations. Now that people want it made public, I will proceed to make it public.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIFIED NATIONAL SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister advise the House of progress towards the establishment of the unified national system of higher education, given that institutions were requested to indicate by the end of October whether they wished to participate in that system? Can the Minister also advise on the progress of moves to provide funding for higher education for next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canning for his question. The unified national system is the system which replaces the current binary system which distinguished between universities and those institutions which were in the advanced education sector. Following the release of the White Paper, I wrote to every institution which had an enrolment in excess of 2,000 full time students, inviting them all to join the new unified national system. I am delighted to inform the honourable member and the House that every university, every institute of technology and every eligible college of advanced education has responded to my invitation and has joined the new unified national system. I think this is important in terms of the development of a bigger and better higher education system in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to realise that in responding to my invitation and in joining the system, the institutions have undertaken commitments, expressed in their own terms, to undertake a review of their internal management; to engage in better credit transfer arrangements and to ensure that those students who undertake work in one institution get appropriate credit when they move to another. They will also implement internal staff and research management plans, introduce a common academic year, and make a determination of equity goals for each institution.

It is important to realise that the decision on the part of each institution was taken freely by its appropriate governing body. I might say to those opposite that those institutions very soberly decided to put aside some of the more hysterical claims of a few including, I might say, the cackling shadow Minister on the other side. It was their own decision. None of them complained of any duress in terms of the invitation that was made to them. It was, therefore, a rebuff for the fearmongers.

I must say that this is not an occasion for me to engage in any self-satisfaction. As far as I am concerned, this is a victory for the higher education system itself. It is a victory for all Australians who will have the opportunity to gain the very substantial benefits that flow from a period of successful participation in the higher education system.

In relation to the last part of the honourable member's question, within the next couple of days we will introduce into this House legislation which will provide the basis for funding over the next triennium for all those institutions, whether in fact they are inside or outside the system. Something like 40,000 new places will be created over the next triennium. There will be a new and historic commitment to equity objectives to ensure that every Australian who is qualified to enter a higher educational institution has the opportunity so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The honourable gentleman will be aware that the projected decline in oil exploration in Australia leads to projections that indicate that in the mid-1990s Australia will be forced to import in the vicinity of $3 billion to $5 billion worth of oil. What is the Government going to do to protect our position, bearing in mind the vital need to ensure that we get access to any oil that should be there?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He will observe that we have conducted our negotiations with the Indonesians on the basis and the assumption that we are the two sovereign powers and nations with rights in this area to be determined. That carries, necessarily, the implication that we do not accept the observations that have been made by the other power to which the honourable member refers.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to report to the honourable member and, through him, to the House, that the negotiations with the Indonesians have proceeded satisfactorily. As the honourable member would be aware, those negotiations have been furthered in the discussions that the Foreign Minister, Senator Evans, has recently conducted in Indonesia. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business seen new research which predicts steep rises in world temperatures? Is the problem serious and how can it be addressed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question. As honourable members will know, this is a matter of great interest to Senator Richardson and me. Senator Richardson, who has the responsibility, is represented in this place by my colleague the Minister for Arts and Territories.
—You have had so many reshuffles, you were not sure.
—Never in my area.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting. The Minister will answer the question.

—The most recent estimates by the British meteorological service is the most serious and most pessimistic one. The service predicts that the world will become 5.2 degrees celsius warmer over a period of between 50 and 100 years. The very sophisticated computer modelling used by the service suggests temperatures of about one to 1 1/2 per cent higher than the next worst prediction. The British prediction assumes a doubling of CO2 in the atmosphere over that period. It also assumes that there will be an increase of temperature-and this is the most serious part-of around 12 degrees celsius at the poles. If we had that degree of increase in temperature, the implications for a melt at the poles would be very serious indeed. It might have a terrible effect on the electorate of Melbourne Ports, the electorate of Denison and every other coastal area that one can imagine.

ANSWER.PARA: Since internationally comparable meteorological records have been kept, 1987 has been the hottest year. All the predictions are that 1988 will prove to be hotter still. That means that four of the hottest years in recorded meteorological history have been experienced in the 1980s. I happened to be in Boston in August in the middle of a very long heatwave. Harvard University was closed for the first time in 352 years because of the heat. There was a combination of excessive industrial ozone around the city of Boston-although there was ozone depletion around the poles-very serious temperature inversions and a heatwave that had gone on for over a month. It was recommended on television that people stay home and not breath the air because the air, it was said, was unhealthful. Apart from getting away from the city of Boston, not much of an alternative was suggested.

There is a very serious consequence for us. We have to recognise that there are two elements in this global warming. One is the human element and the other is the systemic element. There is a lot that we do not know about what is happening to ambient temperature. There is a view that almost all of the contribution is man made. In the United States of America, for example, it is argued that the ambient temperature away from the cities is declining very slightly but that the heat islands around the cities are contributing between 12 and 15 per cent extra heat. The result is that the whole pattern of how we use resources, what we are doing to contribute more CO2 and the rate at which we are knocking out forests internationally raises very serious questions.

The other day I was told that Brazil is losing tropical rainforests at the rate of the area of a football field every second. In 1950, 30 per cent of the ground of the earth was covered by forest. By 1975 the figure was 15 per cent and it is estimated that by the year 2000 it will be 7 1/2 per cent. If we do not have the trees in place to absorb the CO2 and, further, if the trees are chopped down and then burnt so that the CO2 captured in the trees is released into the atmosphere, the implications are very serious. There is also a lot that we do not know about the effect of the global warming on the seas-not just on the level of the seas but on the capacity--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister might bring his answer to a close, interesting though it is.

—We have only a decade or two in which to face up to the implications of the problem. I just conclude by saying that between 3 and 5 November an international greenhouse conference will be conducted, and I think a lot of interest will be generated not just here but internationally. I also ask honourable members to think of what would have happened if the greenhouse effect had so flooded the Maribyrnong River that today's great cultural event at Flemington could not have occurred. It is a very serious problem.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The public concern over the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio to the detriment of Aboriginal people.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. The matter of public importance, which you read, refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: The public concern over the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio to the detriment of Aboriginal people.

In order to pre-empt, I suppose, what might come out in this discussion, in Question Time today the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) reduced this matter to one of accusation and substantiation of accusation. I do not intend to follow the Minister's suggestion that I should make further allegations beyond those which have been made; nor do I intend to use this discussion as an opportunity to vilify individuals or to make outrageous statements or allegations. That is not my style, and it is certainly not the way in which I think matters of this sort ought to be dealt with. What I do want to do is to look at what steps the Minister has taken in relation to allegations that have been made and to question whether or not he has taken the most appropriate steps, having regard to the statements that have been made.

First and foremost, I think it is important that honourable members understand the background against which I speak in matters of this sort. I do so having maintained a degree of interest in Aboriginal affairs questions over the 15 years that I have been in parliament. For some 10 years I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and for eight years, between 1975 and 1983, I chaired that Committee; and I regarded that as a great privilege in terms of my parliamentary responsibilities. I was involved in the writing of reports which I think documented in a most significant way the hardship which Aboriginals suffer and the difficulties they have as the most disadvantaged people, as a class of people, in Australia. I for one would not be a critic of effective programs directed towards the alleviation of the poverty and difficulties that Aboriginals experience. I remind honourable members that in the Aboriginal Health report which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs wrote-it was a unanimous report-dealing with Aboriginals as a class of people, it was stated:

Aboriginal society has changed irrevocably since European settlement in Australia. Entire social groups died as result of disease, dispossession, conflict and, in some cases, massacre. Large numbers of people succumbed to introduced illnesses and to the despair which characterises people dominated by a more powerful and alien society. The heritage of these often destructive contacts with European society has been continuing at inordinately high rates of ill health and poverty, and highly inadequate living conditions compounded by limited opportunities for education and employment. Like other minority groups living in depressed socio-economic circumstances, Aboriginals suffer feelings of worthlessness, apathy and hopelessness.

I could go on and quote from the Aboriginal Legal Aid report, which also documented the extent to which Aboriginals in Australia suffer significantly. It documented the need for assistance, particularly in the area of discrimination and prejudice, as well as the social deprivation that Aboriginals suffer. It is against a background in which I recognise that evidence does support the need for special programs for Aboriginal people and a special and responsible caring attitude that I raise this matter today. If honourable members look at the reports with which I have assisted they will see that I am one who believes that Aboriginals should be involved in the administration of programs. I also acknowledge that there is a learning curve and a necessity to train Aboriginal people in terms of their ability to be able to participate in the delivery of programs. The approaches taken by the previous Government when it was in office were important in developing Aboriginal self-esteem which, in my view, is an important corollary to the efforts that are directed towards specific programs based on need.

It ought to be noted that the efforts to involve Aboriginals in the administration of programs have been going on for quite a long time. Some of the people about whom we are talking have been involved in the administration of public programs for 15 years or more. That is a fact that is often forgotten. However, the success or otherwise of programs that are there for the benefit of Aboriginal people is very much dependent upon public confidence in the programs. There is a need for continuing accountability and effective management if that public confidence is to be maintained. Those who are in a position of leadership have a very special responsibility on behalf of Aboriginals. It is not just those of us in the Parliament and those involved in public life who have that responsibility. Those who accept responsibility for offering leadership within Aboriginal communities also carry with them that leadership role and the need to lead by example.

It is important that the programs that are in place be not brought into disrepute. Regrettably, over a period trust in the administration of programs has been brought into disrepute. It has not come about by outrageous allegations. If one looks at the comments of people who are known for their caring attitude, one can see why we have a problem today. I wish to quote from what was said by the former Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in New South Wales, Pat O'Shane, on the radio program AM this morning. She was introduced as `Aboriginal activist, magistrate and the former Secretary of the New South Wales Department of Aboriginal Affairs' and as welcoming the probe into the ADC. The leader stated:
She says other publicly-funded Aboriginal organisation are ineptly run, and also warrant investigation.
Pat O'Shane went on to say:

One thing I would say is that in my opinion, it's very much overdue. There have been numerous allegations over some considerable years now about the financial management of the ADC and in more recent years, of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

She then went on to talk about the importance of training Aboriginal staff, and that is a matter which I acknowledge. When asked, again, whether other Aboriginal organisations deserve investigation, she replied:
Yes, there are. Yes, there are.
When she was asked `Which ones?', she replied:

I certainly don't intend to name them on this program, publicly. But I'm sure the Government and other authorities can get to the bottom of them. I happen to know that concerns have been expressed directly to the Minister in respect of some organisations around the country, and I'm sure that the Minister, in the fullness of time, will move to investigate those accordingly.

Those comments were from somebody who ought to know. But such comments are not all that new; they were not just made today. Mention was made in Question Time of a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. I do not want to quote from the minority report because the Minister might expect that I was being unduly partisan in doing so, but I understand that the Committee, in the summary of its recommendations, came to this view:

The Committee will, in due course, prepare a more detailed report on the efficiency and effectiveness of the ADC, as well as a confidential report which will be made available to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. This confidential report will deal with information and allegations of a serious nature which have come to the Committee's attention during the inquiry but which are generally peripheral to its terms of reference.
Paragraph 1.10 stated:
A number of other matters brought to the attention of the Committee have involved serious allegations of maladministration which in some instances may lead to criminal prosecution.

So the Minister has had before him, before these questions arose in the Senate Estimates Committee this last week, serious allegations made about administration in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. The fact of the matter is that when we rest for support for Aboriginal programs on Australians-that is, Australians at large-and their perception of fairness, the way in which we deal with these questions is of the utmost importance. When Aboriginals live in the community and have to face non-Aboriginals, their relationships within the community are dependent upon that level of trust; the public confidence that is involved.

I now come to the allegations that have been made. I want only to remind the Minister of the allegations, because reference was made to them extensively in Question Time, by Ann Forward in relation to the Minister's Department. The Minister will recall the question I put to him about the Department and what action he was intending to take regarding the Department itself. The Minister said that he saw the allegations concerning the ADC as being more serious accusations than those in relation to the Department and, for that reason, the Department was not being investigated. But the allegations that have been made by Ann Forward, representing the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA), related to the Department as well. She said:

I have no hesitation in asserting that people have been recruited to the staff of the Department by a number of processes not provided for even in the special provisions established to facilitate entry of Aboriginal personnel.

Her allegations also related to the Aboriginal Development Commission. Her correspondence raised serious questions. The point made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) was of the utmost importance in this matter because he brought out, as the full text of the letter which the Minister may find in Senate Estimates Committee E Hansard at page 281 makes clear, that not only are there malpractices but also those malpractices are not disclosed because those involved-that is, officers-are going to the ACOA, their union, complaining that they may be compromised through fear of reprisals or because they do not wish to be identified as racists or betrayers of the Aboriginal cause. It is interesting that in rebutting that the Minister called for allegations to be made, but in answering another question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today he spoke of the network and the possible problems that people who were introduced to the Minister by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) might face if they were known to have pursued those matters with him.

I am disappointed-that would be an understatement-about the way in which the Minister has responded to these allegations that have been made. They have been allegations which have been made over time. The Minister says that he wants to put them to rest. I am a member of the Public Accounts Committee. I know how the Auditor-General operates. First and foremost, I know that the Auditor-General recently has been complaining about his own ability to undertake tasks which he faces. The Minister has said:

As a result of a meeting with the Commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission in Canberra this morning I have invited the Commonwealth Auditor-General to undertake a comprehensive audit of the Commission.

I do not know what is meant by the term `comprehensive audit'. If it is an audit in the form that the Auditor-General normally undertakes, which comprises about 80 per cent of his work, then it is certainly not the sort of inquiry that will cover the range of matters that have been raised. If it is to be a full efficiency audit, I very much doubt the capacity of the Auditor-General to undertake that task. I certainly doubt his capacity to undertake it in a timely and efficient way that will enable the Parliament to be apprised of the results of his inquiry in proper terms.

In relation to the appointment of officers of the Department of Finance to assist the ADC on financial matters, knowing of the way in which the Department of Finance has a responsibility to assist all departments, I am astonished that it would be suggested that that is an appropriate response. There is clearly only one response that should be undertaken in relation to this matter-that is, a full and complete public inquiry into all the allegations that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), I have been chairperson of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs; so I guess we have something in common in that regard. I have debated issues similar to this with the honourable member on a number of occasions. I make the point that he is a person whom I hold in high regard. The question we are dealing with relates to the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio being to the detriment of Aboriginal people. I will deal briefly with the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). That matter is being addressed. There is no question of it not being addressed. I regret that the matter has been raised in a public way because there is no question that when one pinpoints an area and there are only a limited number of community organisations in that area one may have breached the privacy that those individuals sought. I find that very disturbing indeed. The matter is being addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: We are having this debate today not because of the comments made by the honourable member for Dundas or comments made by one of the other questioners in this House. We are having it because of a series of actions that have occurred over a period both in the Parliament and outside the Parliament. On 10 December last year the Government announced a proposal to amalgamate the areas within my portfolio into a new commission. This exercise we are engaged in at this point in time is a culmination of events. It is a campaign that has been waged since that time. I apologise to some of the people in the gallery for not talking too much about this matter. I am keen to see that I am correct in what I say.

I have been personally subjected to the most outrageous series of press statements. My staff have been subjected to all sorts of harassment. My staff have been harassed by members of this place. One of my staff members was personally abused by a prominent member of the Opposition in the Senate. Accusations have been made of improper practices by my staff. Outrageous claims have been made about the people who went to serve on the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) at my request. Extraordinary broad-brush comments have been made about all of the public servants and others employed in the four areas for which I am responsible. Incredible attacks have been made on Aboriginal people, with the specific purposes of damaging whatever chance we have of getting the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission into place in the latter part of this year. It has been a consis- tent and calculated campaign culminating in the Senate Estimates Committee. A small group of people in the ADC have set about a course of destruction. I hope that they are not aware of the consequences of their actions.

We have had hundreds of questions. The previous speaker talked about getting on with the job. I have tried desperately to get on with the job, but the whole bureaucratic structure that I operate has been bogged down by a series of questions, half-truths and accusations about a black mafia. When Senator Tambling was questioned by the media as to why he used the phrase `a black mafia' his answer was, `Well, the only way I can get some attention from the press is to make an outrageous claim like that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you call it a network?

—The honourable member does not believe that. I use the term as I would have when I was living in the rural areas about the fact that if one pinpoints an area it does not take too long for the people around Mortlake to know who has the big hereford stud farm there. The honourable member knows whom I am talking about. We should not try to deflect the issue.
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins is not in his appropriate seat. Even if he were, he should not interject.

—That is right. I think I have a reasonable reputation in this place for telling the truth. I say to the previous speaker that if he or anybody else has any proof of malpractice, corruption, extortion, nepotism or anything else I will act upon it.
—Will you settle for a prima facie case?

—I will settle for information in private that people want to put to me. I have done that all the time. There are people in this House who tell me things. They do not want me to make it public; they want it checked out. We operate a portfolio which is a minority type of view of the whole government. We cover every single type of policy. I say to the people on the other side of the House that this Government has not done everything right. I have not done everything right. No other Minister who has occupied this position would say that everything has gone right while he has been in the job either. But we have all tried, on both sides of the House. Aboriginal people do not deserve comments such as `the black mafia'. It is unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw one point to the Opposition's attention. There was a whole series of questions asked by Senator Tambling. This is the difficulty we have. Every one of those questions listed does not correspond with the Senate documents. How did he get the numbers wrong? Nearly every single question does not correspond. When Senator Tambling was asked about it, he said something about a typographical error. He must have a pretty crook typist, I would say; he probably did it himself. It is obvious where the information came from. People I have appointed to the board of the ADC systematically have been assassinated around this country for doing me a favour. I have hung back and put up with a lot over the last 12 months. I have put up with a lot of lies and deception by a small group of self-interested people who have told lies right around this nation.

We are engaged in an absolute witch-hunt at the moment. It was put to me, `If you drop off ATSIC, we can come to some agreement'. I am not dropping off ATSIC. The honourable member for Dundas is correct in what he says: Aboriginal Affairs needs rejigging. Most people who work in Aboriginal Affairs want it to be rejigged. The honourable member for Dundas and the reports of the Aboriginal Affairs Committee, when he was chairman and when I was chairman, all say one thing: Aboriginal people want to be involved in the decision-making process. That is why the policies of governments over the years probably have not worked as well as they should have. Too many decisions are made in isolation away from the people who are affected by them. We are trying to change that with the development of ATSIC.

We are limited by time, but I would like to talk about the club-the famous Woden Town Centre club incident splattered across every newspaper in this country. Not one journalist has had the decency to question whether the so-called facts are correct. That is the problem. The `facts', as published, are wrong. I want to put my view on the record. I am totally opposed to the club being given grant moneys. I would not give a poker machine club 1c of public money. I have told the ADC commissioners that. However, I draw to the attention of honourable members the fact that it was not the new commissioners who made the decision. The decision was made in 1986. In 1988 the commissioners were faced with a Coopers and Lybrand report which, incidentally, the club had never seen. The commissioners had a choice of losing $1m or putting in more money to save the club. That is what they were faced with at their first meeting. Despite this fact, Senator Tambling and others have been denigrating and attacking people and writing them off. The honourable member for Dundas knows Lois O'Donoghue. I ask him: Is she part of some black mafia? Is Paddy Dodson part of some black mafia? We could go on. I will refer to other areas. These commissioners had very difficult decisions to make. The problem of Nardoola, for example, which is known to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), goes back to 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't answered his questions.

—Answers will be given very quickly. They have been prepared and will be published quickly. The point is that that problem goes back to 1981, for God's sake. Therefore, how can a new group of commissioners be responsible for that mess?
—We are talking about you.

—I am trying to rectify some injustices. I will take care of myself. People are quick to brand Aboriginal people. It is not fair. It is not fair on those individuals, some of whom lose money to go into these organisations at our request. They lose income. Their price for that is to be maligned. Every one of the accusations that have been made will be investigated.

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise to the honourable member for Dundas, who proposed the matter of public importance, for my addressing some of these points. He said that he was not going to make emotional outbursts and make wild accusations. That is the sort of person he is. He is like that. That is why he always talks on these issues. However, I think that the members of the cheap shot brigade opposite who are trying to score a few points are outrageous. Their day will come, I tell them that. Senator Tambling, who has led the charge to the people in the press gallery, is on the record as saying in terms of the ADC report:

The report before us today by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) is a very commendable one because it looks, as other senators have said, at the story of an organisation that has grown through many growth pains to a position of success.

He went on in the same vein. His remarks were full of praise for the ADC. All of the issues he is now raising stem from that period. I will investigate all of those accusations. I have an open door policy. I will investigate all those issues. However, it is extremely difficult when one is questioned about the integrity of people whom one knows to be honest and hardworking and whose crime has been to say, `Look, under the Act we 10 people are charged with administering this body. You set it up. We are the commissioners'. Their crime has been that they have dared to ask the bureaucracy and the ADC for an opportunity to look at documents before they are sent out. They have asked, `Let us have a look at the documents before you present them to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. Let us look at the Senate document before you present it under our banner'. What happens to those people? The Senate has them up on a breach of privilege, for God's sake! How, for example, would the managing directors of Myers or BHP get away with just whacking out their annual reports without showing them to anybody? These people have been attacked in the most vicious, political and dishonest way ever. Honourable members opposite ought to be ashamed of themselves. Honourable members opposite can laugh, but it is true. It is damned true. The public ought to understand that. They ought to understand that this is the biggest witch-hunt ever.

There are mistakes made in Aboriginal affairs. If we talk to Aboriginal people, they will agree. But they are not crooks and they are not members of the mafia. That sort of cheap shot is having terrible repercussions around this country. People are scoring points. The honourable member for Dundas knows how the system works. People in the community are saying, `See, we told you so'. People are striving to improve the lot of their communities. The Government is wanting to get on and implement the programs it has provided funding for this year. However, what have we got? We have got a massive conspiracy and a bog-down. There is no need for it. We have had the actions of Senator Tambling and Senator Short. Let us look at Senator Short, who funded his election preselection battle in 1975, when he worked for the Treasury, out of travel expenses. Let us analyse the way we spend travel allowances in this place. How dare those in the Senate question who lives with whom? If we tried that out here, we would go blind trying to work out who lived with whom. However, Aboriginal people are fair game to be attacked.

I say to honourable members opposite that the problems will be addressed. They will be fixed. Any honourable member opposite can check whether I am doing that. The bureaucracy is not crook. The Aboriginal communities are not crook. The reason we are bringing people in to look at the Aboriginal Development Commission is to prove the very point that Aboriginal people are decent and want to get on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said in a preamble to his speech that he regretted that he had to comment on this situation. I regret too that I have to comment on a situation of the Government's making-a situation which is seriously harming, as the matter of public importance states, the cause of Aboriginal advancement in this country. Over the last five years the Government has achieved two very clear things in Aboriginal affairs. Firstly, there is the Government's self-indulgent rhetoric about national land rights and treaties. This action by the Government has disillusioned Aboriginals and alienated non-Aboriginals. Secondly, the Government's incompetent oversight of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs has discredited the difficult task of Aboriginal development in the eyes of the taxpaying community. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) dismisses the claims made against his administration as mere politicking. His departmental secretary has tried to portray those claims as part of a racist witch-hunt. I consider both comments to be very insulting to this Parliament and untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: The question before us today is this: Who is responsible for this damaging public exposure of departmental and Aboriginal Development Commission malpractice? Is it the Opposition, which is duty bound to raise publicly questions concerning abuse of public office and wastage of public moneys? Or is it the Government, whose incompetence produced the situation and whose refusal to acknowledge the problem has forced the matter to be raised publicly in the manner that it has? The two questions before us subsequently are these: Exactly what is going on in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs? Why have senior union leaders, Aboriginal leaders and the Opposition been forced to use Estimates committees, Question Time, matters of public importance and the media to get the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to do his job?

The point is that what has now been made public by a responsible Opposition has been known to most observers for over 12 months. As Pat O'Shane confirmed this morning on the radio, everyone with anything to do with Aboriginal affairs knows that over the last five years the tardiness of the Government's management has seen incompetence develop and rorts take over. They are not my words. Everyone has given the Minister time to settle in and then, on many occasions, the benefit of the doubt. I take his word that he has worked extremely hard and is really taking his portfolio seriously, but many areas do come up for question. But now it is time for the Parliament and the people to be provided with the answers to the questions which have surfaced over the last week.

The point is that when the Minister greets with surprise news of serious malpractice and patronage in his portfolio, either he is not being totally honest or he is revealing, it seems, how out of touch he is with his portfolio administration. How on earth can these things happen otherwise? The latter situation must be looked at as a real possibility.

For the last five years, agenda formulation in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio has been dominated by political activists. That is a very significant point. These activists have been concerned more with the higher abstract concern of sovereignty over what they call the Euro-Australian federal state, and less with the mundane priorities of good health, sound education and income self- reliance for Aboriginals. The preoccupation with political semantics and political structures reached its peak under the current Minister. Indeed, this Minister, in his brief period as Minister, has focused totally on his proposed treaty and his grand political plan known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). As the evidence now before us shows, that preoccupation has led to the neglect of the oversight of his portfolio to the extent that he has had to call in the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance to tell him what is going on in his Department and to suggest a solution in regard to what appears to be endemic mismanagement, distorted priorities and patronage.

If this issue were just about politics, then the Opposition would have settled for scoring points off an embattled Minister at Question Time. But it is more important than that. If we want to reinforce stereotypes in the community about fraud by blacks and about the vanity of efforts to help Aboriginal communities, the best way to go is the way of incompetence in allocating and monitoring funds and power in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Margaret Valadian from the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute stated:
To allow for lower than normal levels of accountability in Aboriginal affairs is to insult the intelligence of Aboriginal people.

But it is also to put at risk the support for Aboriginal advancement amongst non- Aboriginals which achieved such significant levels in the late 1960s and the late 1970s under coalition governments. Public concern about the administration of this portfolio is eroding that once-significant consensus, to the detriment of the cause of Aboriginal development.

Of course, mismanagement of funds allocated to this portfolio has a more direct consequence for Aboriginal people: it deprives them of the means to lift themselves out of the disadvantage which oppresses them. We hear a lot of talk today about the fact that the Aboriginal people in Australia-and there is absolutely no denying it-are the most disadvantaged people that we have. Enormous amounts of money are being redirected to other areas-not to the areas that will allow them to lift themselves out of these tremendous disadvantages which oppress them so much in so many different areas. Money absorbed by an inefficient or confused bureaucracy presents for Aboriginals what economists call an opportunity cost. Recent research by Professor Treadgold suggests that Aboriginal people have gained little from 10 years of funding this portfolio. So there needs to be a tremendous re-examination of the whole matter. The Minister has suggested that this, indeed, is the case. The debate today gives us an insight into why that research is probably quite accurate. What would best serve Aboriginal advancement is not the grandiose ATSIC blueprints of the Minister, or the dangerous treaty proposals of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); rather, what would best suit Aboriginal people is a government with its priorities in order, a Minister concerned with excellence in his portfolio, and a bureaucracy which minimises-I emphasise that word-its share of the funds allocated to help Aboriginals maximise their efforts to overcome their problems at the community level. The Minister says that he will clean up his Department and related bodies. He denies, however, it seems, both the gravity of the problem and the fact that the situation is as serious as it is, because he has refused to act earlier. I say that with great concern.

The Opposition comes here today, first, to say that we believe the Minister through his inactivity-even though he has made great efforts, as he claims-has harmed the trust of this place and of the people of Australia by his tardy oversight of areas for which he is responsible. I mention the fact that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has been waiting for almost a year for answers to some questions that he has had on notice. Secondly, and more significantly, the Opposition points to the obvious-that the greatest harm being done in this sorry situation is that being done to Aboriginal people and Aboriginal advancement. I put it to the House that on both counts the Minister and the Government deserve strong criticism.
