TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The first purpose of this new Privacy Bill is, like its 1986 predecessor, to regulate the collection, handling and use by Commonwealth departments and agencies of information about individuals. The Privacy Bill will establish an independent privacy guardian, the Privacy Commissioner, within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, to oversee these matters and handle complaints. In addition, the Bill provides guidelines for the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information which all tax file number information users are required to comply with.

At the present time, our privacy rights are protected by various existing branches of the law which provide limited protection. The laws on defamation, breach of confidence, copyright and passing off can be used to prevent unauthorised circulation of personal information or comment in various circumstances. Also, statutory secrecy provisions in Commonwealth legislation such as section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the vigilance of parliamentary bodies and other community groups have been important in maintaining and promoting the individual's right to privacy.

The enormous developments in technology for the processing of information are providing new and, in some respects, undesirable opportunities for the greater use of personal information. These developments have focused attention on the need for the regulation of the collection and use of personal information by government agencies and for an independent community spokesperson for privacy. The Privacy Commissioner will ensure that some balance is brought to the debate as to the desirability of using the opportunities provided by new information technology to their fullest extent.

There is no doubt that with the greater range of services being provided, governments are accumulating more personal information about individuals in order to provide those services efficiently and effectively. This, together with the ever-increasing capacity of modern computers to search and process information, offers significant potential for invasion of personal privacy by misuse. Also, the legitimate needs of agencies in acquiring personal information and the use made of it must be balanced against the need to sustain personal privacy. It is now clear that legislation is necessary to meet the challenge that information technology is posing for the individual's right to retain some measure of personal privacy. Again, the Privacy Commissioner will have a role in providing advice to government in this area.

Internationally, there is an increasing trend for governments to enact privacy legislation. The Council of Europe's Convention on Data Protection and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) guidelines on personal privacy have been developed to encourage countries to take privacy protection measures. Australia has formally signified its intention to adhere to the guidelines and in so doing to take into account in any privacy legislation the principles set out in those guidelines. Most European countries, the United States of America and Canada have enacted privacy protection legislation. It is now an appropriate time for Australia to enact such legislation.

The Government has been giving detailed consideration for some time to comprehensive information privacy protection legislation. In December 1983 a very detailed report and recommendations were received from the Law Reform Commission following a reference to the Commission in 1976. The recommendations included draft legislation which drew on the OECD guidelines. In 1986 this Government introduced privacy legislation. There has been considerable comment and debate on the proposals contained in that Bill. The Government has taken account of those comments in formulating the current Bill.

The scheme of the Privacy Bill is to enunciate a series of rules, called information privacy principles, which are based on the principles recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its draft legislation. Under the principles, Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector. An agency collecting personal information from the individual to whom the information relates must see that that person is generally aware of such things as the purpose for which the information is being collected, whether it is compulsory to supply that information and the collector's usual disclosure practices in relation to that information. The principles require agencies, when both collecting and retaining information, to see that it is relevant to the purpose of collection, up-to-date and complete. Before using any information, agencies must also check its accuracy. `Personal information' is widely defined to include anything-act, true or false, or opinion-that reasonably identifies an individual.

The principles require agencies to store information records securely against loss or misuse. They are to provide information about the types of personal information they hold. Subject to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 exemptions they are to provide an individual with access to his or her personal information records and to make corrections for accuracy, relevance and completeness. Subject to certain specific exceptions, notably for law enforcement and preservation of life, information may not be used for a purpose or disclosed to a person other than with the agreement of the individual concerned. The exceptions recognise that any claim for privacy by an individual must be considered against equally justified claims by other individuals and the community.

This legislation also recognises the special nature of medical research, in particular epidemiological research. To that end provision has been made to give the Privacy Commissioner and the National Health and Medical Research Council a role in the development and approval of privacy guidelines in the conduct of such research. Commonwealth agencies will be required to comply with the information privacy principles. A breach of the principles will be deemed by the Bill to be an `interference with privacy'. Under the Bill an individual will be able to complain to the Privacy Commissioner about alleged interferences with privacy, who will attempt to resolve the allegations by conciliation and, failing that, make binding determinations against agencies, including determinations for compensation and costs. In effect, the Privacy Commissioner will be the means by which there will be accountability to the public on the use by government of their personal information.

The Commissioner will be empowered to undertake random audits of agencies' databases to ensure their adherence to the information privacy principles. To help agencies achieve compliance with the principles, the Privacy Commissioner will be able to give advisory opinions, issue guidelines and examine proposed enactments for privacy implications. Where an agency believes that a current or proposed practice that may breach the principles is nevertheless essential to its operations, it will be able to seek from the Commissioner a determination allowing the practice to continue or go ahead without risk of its being found to be an interference with privacy. Such a determination may be granted only if the Commissioner is satisfied that the public interest in permitting the practice substantially outweighs the public interest in adherence to the principles. Such determinations will be able to be disallowed by the Parliament. The information privacy principles in the Privacy Bill will apply to Commonwealth departments and agencies to the same extent that the Freedom of Information Act applies to them.

Since the 1986 Bill the Government has introduced the tax file number legislation which has substantial penalties for unauthorised requests for, recording and disclosure of tax file numbers. The Privacy Bill supplements those protections by providing additional privacy protections by way of requiring that tax file number users comply with statutory guidelines. The Privacy Commissioner, in consultation with the proposed Privacy Advisory Committee, will issue guidelines for the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information to assist the Commissioner of Taxation and all bodies and individuals lawfully using tax file numbers on what measures should be taken to protect privacy interests. These guidelines will be reviewable by the Parliament which will be able to disallow them.

To ensure that tax file number legislation does not come into operation without adequate privacy protection measures being in place, the Bill includes interim guidelines. These are expressed in broad and general terms, and it is expected that after consultation they will be replaced by more specific guidelines.

The Privacy Commissioner will be able to investigate complaints about alleged misuse of tax file numbers and attempt to conciliate and, failing that, make determinations, including a determination for compensation or costs. Such determinations will not be formally binding as between the parties. If compliance with the Privacy Commissioner's determination is not forthcoming, either the Privacy Commissioner or the complainant will be able to apply to the Federal Court of Australia to have the determinations enforced. Where a complaint is made and the Privacy Commissioner considers that there may be a breach of the offence provisions of the Taxation Administration Act 1953, the Privacy Commissioner is required to inform the appropriate law enforcement authorities of the complaint and suspend his investigations until the relevant law enforcement processes are completed.

I turn to the Government's approach to privacy regulation in relation to the private sector. As I have indicated, the information privacy principles apply only to Commonwealth agencies. Unlike the tax file number guidelines they do not apply to the private sector. The Privacy Commissioner is required to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information that are consistent with the OECD guidelines on personal privacy. The Commissioner is required to report annually to the Government on the success of these arrangements. The Commissioner will be available to advise private sector bodies on privacy measures and it is hoped that corporations will take significant steps in the future in this regard. The Government will reassess this approach following advice from the Privacy Commissioner. Of course, the tax file number guidelines will apply to the private sector.

I mentioned earlier that the law of confidence is an important existing means of protecting privacy in some circumstances. The Bill includes some limited extensions of the law of confidence recommended by the Law Reform Commission which will further enhance privacy protection. The Bill also includes amendments of the Freedom of Information Act to extend the opportunities for individuals to have access to their personal affairs records and establishes the requirement for such individuals to be alerted to requests for access to those records by others. It also makes essentially machinery amendments to ensure that privacy complaints wrongly directed to other agencies are transferred to the Privacy Commissioner for investigation under the Privacy Bill without inconvenience to the complainant. The Office of Privacy Commissioner, to be established under the Privacy Bill, is expected to have a direct cost to the Government of around $970,000 in a full-year operation.

The Privacy Bill is the first legislation in Australia to establish a comprehensive code of privacy protection and to provide an enforceable right to privacy. It will provide a practical means for persons who have been adversely affected by a failure to comply with those standards to seek redress. It will also provide an effective mechanism for safeguarding the rights of individuals in relation to the tax file number scheme. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill represents the final part of the package of legislation introduced by the Government to establish self-government for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The Bill makes provision for necessary transitional and consequential matters arising from the establishment of the ACT as a body politic by the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988. Its object is to ensure that the normal business of government and existing rights enjoyed by residents and transferred staff continue during the transfer of functions from the Commonwealth to the ACT. The Government will ensure that the transfer of power to ACT residents and its elected government is smooth and with as little disruption as possible to their everyday lives.

The Commonwealth is particularly concerned to look after the interests of staff who are to be transferred to the employment of the ACT. Provisions in this Bill ensure the preservation of existing conditions of service under various Commonwealth legislation, including conditions relating to workers' compensation, long service leave, maternity leave, superannuation and grievance appeals. The ACT will be free, of course, to make its own provisions for its employees, but before it may do so consultations must take place with the Commonwealth and relevant unions.

The Bill makes a number of interim arrangements relating to administrative law. The Bill also provides for the transfer to the ACT of rights, assets and contracts of the Commonwealth which relate to transferred functions. Specific provision is made to transfer to the ACT Commonwealth moneys applied in the Territory for territorial purposes and to protect appropriately the financial interests of the Commonwealth. The provisions of this Bill will, in themselves, have no financial impact on the Commonwealth other than in the context of proposed financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the ACT.

I will now address the various parts of the Bill. Part I deals with commencement and interpretative matters. Part II details the various transitional matters I have mentioned before and allows any further necessary consequential and transitional matters to be dealt with by the regulations or ACT ordinance. Part III contains a number of schedules which effect modifications and amendments to various Commonwealth legislation.

Schedules 1 to 4 contain modifications to Commonwealth employment legislation in its application to staff transferred to the employment of the Territory. The modifications recognise that such staff will be answerable to Territory Ministers and the ACT Legislative Assembly. By and large, amendments detailed in schedule 5 ensure that, for the purposes of the application of various Commonwealth Acts, the ACT is treated in the same manner as are the States and the Northern Territory. Schedule 5 also contains amendments to place the government of Jervis Bay on the same footing as other Commonwealth Territories which do not have self-government.

As I have said in relation to the introduction of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, the transfer of functions from the Commonwealth to the ACT represents a challenge for the people of the ACT. For the first time, they will have a real say in how they are governed. I am confident they will exercise the rights and accept the obligations which other Australians who live outside the ACT take for granted. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Bill to amend the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987 was introduced into this House on Wednesday, 12 October this year. The background to this legislation is as follows: on 1 January 1988 the marketing of crude oil was deregulated. This meant that the Government ceased to determine import parity pricing, which was the basis of calculating crude oil excise. Instead, the calculation of the crude oil excise is now based on the volume weighted average of realised prices for all sales of Bass Strait crude oil. This price is determined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) under the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Since deregulation commenced on, as I said, 1 January, certain types of crude oil transactions have occurred which are not strictly covered by the 1987 Act. Examples of such transactions are barter deals, exchanges and conversion of oil to products which are then sold-commonly known in the industry as tolling. In other words, arrangements are entered into under which the producer does not sell the oil directly but offloads it for profit without the exchange of moneys usual in a commercial operation. I should point out that a process of appeal by producers dissatisfied with the Minister's determination remains for those types of transactions as it does under the principal Act.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy assures us in his second reading speech that it is not possible to specify the amount which will be raised as a result of these transactions being subject to his determination. So the only thing that can safely be said about the financial impact of the legislation before the House is that it will obviously increase revenue to the Government. Incidentally, the total revenue from the crude oil excise in 1988-89 is estimated to be $1.4 billion.

While the Opposition does not oppose the Bill before the House, I wish to place it in context. To do so will necessitate some observations on my part on the present state of the oil industry as well as future trends. The importance of the oil industry to Australia is self-evident and certainly I nor anyone else in this place need dwell upon it. Total excise duty from crude oil, liquid petroleum gas and petroleum products represents some 10 per cent of all Government revenue. A ball park figure in monetary terms is $9 billion. It is difficult to estimate exactly the number of people directly and indirectly employed as a result of the petroleum industry but the number is estimated to be at least 120,000. In reality the figure is probably much higher. Oil supplies 41 per cent of Australia's energy needs. In addition, over the years Australia has exported large quantities of oil with an obvious beneficial effect on our balance of payments. Self-sufficiency in oil has aided immeasurably in Australia's growth as a nation.

All this, however, is rapidly changing-for two principal reasons. First, oil reserves are being depleted and production is in decline. Currently, in net terms, Australia is 90 per cent self-sufficient. By the early 1990s self-sufficiency is expected to decline, in net terms, to about 65 per cent. Without further discoveries and the development of new fields, we are likely to be only 20 to 30 per cent self-sufficient by the year 2000. The Australian Minerals and Energy Council forecasts that Commonwealth revenues from crude oil will halve to $1 billion per annum by the early 1990s and drop further to $165m by the year 2000.

The second reason why Australia is complacent in taking for granted self-sufficiency and the economic benefits that flow so freely is that the price of oil has crashed in recent months. Even the most optimistic forecasts would have us believe that prices will remain low for a long time to come. It is always hazardous trying to estimate the future price of oil, but it seems that it is likely to hover around $US10 a barrel into the early 1990s and then fluctuate between $US10 and $US20 a barrel for the remainder of the decade. But some pessimists would have us believe that the price will go well below $US10 per barrel. Naturally, that remains to be seen but, even so, nobody can take any joy from any of the estimates made by some of the most sophisticated research institutes in the world.

Naturally, this drop in the price of oil has had a drastic effect on the level of exploration undertaken by the oil companies. To put it simply, unless the Government tackles both these problems-and they are intertwined-Australia will face an economic crisis. We suffer a reduction in revenue while increasing outgoings. To deal with our future, the Government has to re-examine the articles of faith which have governed its approach to the oil industry to date. I refer principally but not exclusively to the tax regime that governs the oil industry. Whilst I believe that the Government must look afresh at its conduct of issues such as government regulation and industrial relations, I will concentrate my remarks this afternoon on the tax regime.

The taxes imposed on the oil industry can be collectively defined as secondary taxes; that is, they are taxes in addition to the corporate income tax. There is, firstly, the imposition of royalties. Royalties are payable on crude oil production and are based on the wellhead value of the oil. Then there is the crude oil excise levy, which is under discussion in the House at present. The maximum rate of 87 per cent was reduced to 80 per cent in August 1986 after the very steep drop in world oil prices led to a cessation of oil exports. The effective rate is scheduled to be reduced to 75 per cent over the next five years.

We may also take into account the resource rent tax, the subject of a very controversial piece of legislation which was passed in December 1987. The resource rent tax replaces the royalties and the crude oil excise levy for new offshore fields. A further form of secondary taxation is the excise duty on petroleum products. The excise duty on petrol is adjusted twice a year according to increases in the consumer price index-on 1 February and 1 August.

One certainly does not have to be an Einstein to realise that the oil and petroleum industry is taxed extremely heavily. When times were good, which was really the case until the 1980s, there may have been justification for government getting in for its take of this natural resource, but there is a new reality which I am very concerned the Government is not properly taking into account. When we have declining reserves combined with a massive fall in the return on investment because of the drastic fall in oil prices, the Government has to look afresh at the tax regime-not out of sympathy for any corporation but simply out of self-interest. That requires a rethinking on the part of government.

It is terribly important that the Government does not regard the oil industry or, for that matter, any of the energy industries in Australia as something akin to a production line whereby one can churn out the same product endlessly at more or less the same cost and one is assured of production. As it was put to me by one senior participant in the petroleum industry, the industry is not like a jam factory. The reason, of course, is that oil is a non-renewable resource. Once it is tapped and used, we have to explore and replenish the stock. Therefore, exploration is the lifeblood of the oil industry. Government taxes must be so structured as to encourage exploration, not act as a disincentive.

Let me take as an example the offshore production of Bass Strait, which is next to my electorate of Gippsland. In Gippsland the Government is reducing the top marginal excise rate by way of a number of steps from 87 per cent prior to the world oil price collapse of 1986 to 75 per cent from about mid-1989. When royalties of 12 1/2 per cent-one of those iniquitous, or ubiquitous, secondary taxes that I spoke of earlier-and a corporate income tax of 39 per cent are included, the government tax on each barrel from mid-1989 will still be 87 per cent of the selling price. An example of how government can encourage exploration is the announcement in the middle of last year-July, if my memory serves me correctly-of a 30 million barrel excise holiday on new developments in Gippsland. This was a step in the right direction, because it has encouraged Esso not only to explore but also to develop smaller fields. Two which will will be on stream within the next 12 months, and planning for the tapping of which is already well advanced, are Dolphin and Perch. They will be developed by unmanned rigs-a quite fascinating engineering development in itself. This is a very good example of where the Government provides an incentive to the industry to continue its exploration efforts. These smaller fields which would not be developed at all if the same level of excise that applies to some of the more established larger fields were to apply. So I welcome the Goverment's concession, albeit somewhat small in the scale of things, that there will be no excise for fields which produce less than 30 million barrels.

The Government must understand the industry. It must assist the industry to explore, to replenish the oil used. It is a constant battle for the industry to discover new fields. It is high risk and it is expensive. The system has drastically changed since those halcyon days of past decades when it seemed that the oil would flow for all of eternity. I am reminded of the memorable television show, the Beverly Hillbillies. That hillbilly family came to fame and fortune by the accidental discovery of oil on its Texas farm and was funded endlessly by this continuous stream of oil. In many ways Australia has acted as did Jed Clampett and his family. We in this country never thought that we would have to face up to the fact that we would have to rely very heavily so soon on oil imports. We never had to face up to the fact that revenue gained from the oil industry would fall so drastically and so quickly-so much that Esso and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), partners in the Gippsland Basin, have shut in production to the tune of 25,000 barrels per day because to continue to produce the amount they were producing would cost them very dearly.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be only too well aware, Esso and BHP have approached the Government and suggested that economically they may be forced to shut in 80,000 barrels per day-in the order of one-fifth of the production from the Gippsland fields. That would be an economic decision on the part of Esso and BHP as well as the Government. But the truth is that the seriousness of the situation must surely be brought home to the Government. Frankly, in my view, if the economics show that continued production of 80,000 barrels per day will cause a loss to Esso and BHP, the Government has no choice but to lower the excise levy. The arithmetic would clearly show that, if no profit is made by BHP and Esso and, rather, a loss is sustained, the Government really has no choice but to cut the excise. After all, it is far better to collect a lower excise from a greater volume than to collect a higher excise from a smaller volume.

The chickens have come home to roost. It is not something for which I wish to lay the blame entirely at the feet of this Government. Regrettably, past governments have also placed too much reliance on the revenue creamed off the oil industry. But the gravy train for all Australians is grinding to a halt. I am not convinced that this Government is going to provide the stimulus and incentive to the oil industry by way of lower secondary taxation, which, I hasten to add, I am opposed to in principle. The return of a Liberal-National Party government would see an easing of the burden and a decrease in the reliance on secondary taxation.

In my view, a tax regime on resources should always be based on people's ability to pay. It should be based on profitability. But that is not what is happening now. What is happening under this Government-and this extends right across the resources sector-is that the tax regime is non-profit based. This affects competitiveness because it affects the cost of production. Tax after competition on the free market when a profit is made is legitimate; that is how it ought to be. But we are finding that there are government charges, royalties and a whole number of other government takes that affect the competitiveness of the resources sector.

The Government replies to such an argument by declaring that it is not in the business of taking risks. It wants assured revenues. Petroleum and mining are high risk ventures. But taxes which are non-profit based and all of the related charges affect competitiveness and act as a disincentive to exploration. There is no relief when relief is necessary. As profit diminishes, so will taxation in the long run. That is the message that the Government has to heed. If profits are abnormally high, the Government takes a share by way of profit based tax, or corporate taxation, but a lack of competitiveness will diminish the profit. So the Government might get a large take on the present volume, but it will win out more if exploration continues and new fields are found and developed.

If I may digress from the petroleum debate before the House at present, let me take, for example, the question of a tax on the gold industry. This matter comes into the argument about the tax regime on our resources. People say, `Why should the gold industry not be taxed in the same way everybody else is?' Farmers in my own electorate of Gippsland say to me, `I pay tax; why is the gold industry not taxed?' This argument then suggests that there should be equity between all taxpayers. I find that an argument worthy of Gough Whitlam; it is very socialistic in its terms. What those people in effect are saying is that we should be dragging every industry down to the same level of taxation. I believe that the gold industry should be serving as an example for all resource based taxes, because the tax regime applicable to the gold industry has led to a boom in that industry. Does anybody really believe that imposing a tax on the gold industry would bring about a lessening of tax anywhere else? Rather, the gold industry should be serving as the model; it should not be regarded as the anomaly. If we put a brake on the gold industry as it bowls along, we will stop its progress dead in its tracks. Whole towns in Western Australia that I have visited have been established or expanded only because of the growth in the gold industry. I could speak at length on this issue, but I will return to it another day when we are debating legislation which specifically refers to the issue.

It is argued that we should be developing alternative sources of fuel-synthetic fuels, liquefied petroleum gas and natural gas. Naturally, all of this amounts to a great idea, but it is not going to do very much, at least in the short term. It is great to develop these alternative sources, but they will not come on stream for a very long time and will contribute to only a small proportion of our energy needs. Increased exploration is the answer. The Government is not allowing optimum development and people are missing out. The national interest has to be considered. It is not in the national interest for our petroleum industry to wither on the vine: rather, it is in the national interest, because of the dependence of government on oil revenue, to continue exploration and to encourage development. Secondary taxes killed off the resources boom in the early 1980s because profits could not be ploughed back into expansion, further exploration.

The best service that government can render the petroleum industry or, for that matter, any resource-based industry is to stay out of it. It does not want assistance, but neither does it want distortions. As I have argued, a reduction in excise by this Government has already borne fruit. Two fields are being developed in Gippsland which would not otherwise have been even considered as an economic proposition. Indeed, a number of existing rigs in Bass Strait could be expanded if the excise was lower. This Government assumes that old oil cannot be better tapped, but it should not assume that a number of those fields in Gippsland would not be extended if there was not a more favourable excise regime.

The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. After all, if we are to have a system of determining the crude oil excise, we cannot have exceptions or loopholes. I might add that the industry itself accepts that. However, the Opposition is very concerned that this Government is showing no serious intent to phase out the crude oil excise with an end objective of doing away with it altogether. Naturally, that involves questions of fiscal policy. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has told us time and again in this place that he does not intend reducing government expenditure-in other words, decreasing the Government's reliance on taxation revenue-before the next Federal Budget. How serious then is the Government about reducing the level of government expenditure so as to allow it to decrease the taxes imposed not just on the oil industry but on ordinary taxpayers? It is only when we decrease our junkie-like dependence on revenue from the oil industry that we are likely to be able to provide the incentive for further exploration. Self-interest alone determines that we do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take up the last point made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) because he seemed to contradict himself. In the body of his speech he talked about the need to cut the tax, as he put it, that has been placed on the petroleum industry. Then, at the end of his speech, he said that the Government has a responsibility to cut its expenditure. I would like the honourable member to sit down with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and tell us what costs he has just been talking about.
—Health?

—He says `health'. I would like him to say in which areas he wants to cut down on expenditure and how much money he wants to give back to the oil companies. He mentioned earlier that the oil industry was of national interest. I agree with him totally: it is a vitally important industry; it is central to every day life; and it is vital to the economic development of this country. However, I would suggest that many people who are listening to this debate or who read Hansard would appreciate that as government gains taxes from the oil industry, the people of this country are the beneficiaries. Whether the tax on a barrel of oil is 80 per cent or more, it is the people who ultimately benefit because they get the schools, the roads, the defence advantages, health and so on. I found it a very difficult argument for the honourable member for Gippsland to pursue when he said that we should cut this back.

SPEECH.PARA: While the honourable member was speaking I quickly took out some figures. I found that of all the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries-we are talking about 24 Western developed countries-Australia has the fourth cheapest fuel. Only the United States of America, Canada and Turkey have cheaper fuel than we have. If we suddenly reduce taxes I ask the honourable member to consider whether the oil companies will reduce the price to the consumer. I do not think there is evidence that that is so, because many of the countries in that list of 24 have lower taxes on their oil industries than we have, yet the price of their fuel is higher. There may be distribution components and so on, but it is not as simple as the honourable member put it. If we must have such taxes, I would like to see them placed on those companies which make high profits and those companies which would in turn take their profits outside this country. I would rather them stay here, whether the rate is 80 per cent or not. I do not like high fuel costs because I live in a country area. However, I would rather the money stay here for the benefit of all Australians, instead of being put in the pockets of the overseas shareholders of oil companies.

As I have said, the oil industry is vital to us. It requires massive capital investment. Recently I met with an oil company to talk through that issue. As many honourable members would know, at this moment the oil companies of Australia want to rationalise the industry. They want to cut back on the number of sites-some 10,000 sites throughout this country. It has been suggested that they want to cut back by at least one-third. They argue that there is massive capital investment involved in exploration and refining, distribution and finally retailing, and that they need a maximum return. They want to see a major restructuring. That is on their agenda, particularly in the retailing sector. New agreements are being floated around. Those who represent the retailers through their association, both at the State and national levels, are concerned about those agreements because it seems that a heavy-handedness is appearing in some of the conditions being pursued. I understand that companies have to get a return. They are investing not just millions of dollars but hundreds of millions of dollars throughout this nation. However, I am not sure that some of the proposals they are putting forward are in the interests of consumers.

I have noted some of the new franchise arrangements that are being argued-the new wholesaling rules that are being considered. There have been suggestions that there should be key money, premiums on rent or franchise fees. When companies put forward such ideas they often forget that the ultimate payer is the consumer. That seems to have been forgotten here because companies have said that a retailer will have to put only $15,000 up front. However, ultimately that $15,000-others have suggested that it may be $50,000-will be passed back. If the franchise fee is $50,000 it means an extra $1,000 per week that that proprietor of an oil retailing firm has to borrow, find or at least pay over to a company. It is money that he will not have to enable him to employ people. It is money that is coming out of his very slim profits.

I appreciate that there have been limited returns for some companies. I realise also that if we compare some of the figures that have been announced companies probably would have been better investing in other areas, certainly in different sites. But that has been the structure of the oil distribution industry in this country. There is certainly a need for greater efficiency. That is part of the pressure. There is also certainly a need for more business-like practices. I accept the desire of any company to get a higher return for its investment, but I question the new franchise arrangements, the rental premiums and what this will mean ultimately to the consumer and to the 10,000 retailers out there in the marketplace. If a third of them go, there will be a loss of some 30,000 to 40,000 jobs spread across the country. My State of Queensland has some 1,600 petrol retailers and is looking at a loss of some 500 sites. That means fewer distribution points, but it also means fewer people in the small business area. It means fewer jobs. For what reason? It is to give greater profits to the oil companies.

I also accept the need for the argument as to economies of scale. I know that there are some sites that push through only 15,000 or 20,000 litres of fuel per month. The companies have marked a threshold, saying that it ought to be around 200,000. That sounds all right in theory; but what about the small business people who in some cases have invested years of their lives in these businesses in the small towns? What about the workers who depend on their income from working in the service station industry on a part time or full time basis?

I accept that there is a need to think through alternatives. As the chairman of the Government members consumer affairs committee, I am also thinking about rack pricing. Rack pricing is a proposal whereby any dealer should have access to the lowest wholesale price being offered. There is good argument for this because at the moment we hear about the jobbers-those people who are able to go to the oil companies and buy 700,000 or a million litres of fuel. I have seen examples of their getting it for 6c a litre cheaper than the set wholesale price. In a few isolated instances they get it for up to 10c a litre cheaper than the set wholesale price. The strange part about it is that, while the other 9,999 retailers who service the community have to pay cash for their products, these jobbers-these middlemen-are given credit. Sometimes they are given up to 60 days credit on the fuel they get at a discounted price. The oil companies then come back and cry poor. They say, `Things are wrong. We have to do something about it'.

I would like us to give more consideration to rack pricing if it ultimately means a better overall price to the consumer and to industry. We have seen the fluctuations. We have seen fuel prices rise from 43c to 53c in the cities. In some areas of my electorate they go as high as 63c. It is a lot of money to pay. Where there is no competition, that is where the price is held. Any measure that is going to bring down the price to the consumer and raise the profitability to the retailer I would certainly be interested in looking at very carefully and supporting. It has to be done with dialogue.

The heavy-handed approach being taken by some companies has to be condemned. I do not want to name those companies which are pursuing this line. However, I praise those which are not. Recently, Esso Australia Ltd sat down with me and talked the issue through. I know that Mobil Oil Australia Ltd is prepared to go to its retailers, sit down and discuss these provisions. But there are others which are just not doing that. They are taking a very heavy-handed approach. They are drawing a line because they know that in September next year the provisions of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act of 1980 come up for conclusion. It means that the protections they have had over that nine-year period are going to disappear.

Some of these companies are drawing a line and saying, `This is the new contract. You accept it now, before September next year, or else we will give your franchise agreement to someone else. You accept these horrible conditions, these conditions that could send you broke, or else'. Some of those conditions simply should not be allowed. The dictatorial powers of entry so that they can go on site at any time should not be allowed. In some cases 48 hours notice to quit is provided for. How can people invest properly in a business, give reasonable certainty to their staff and be willing to go to a bank and borrow what could be hundreds of thousands of dollars when they know that they could end up walking out of that site within 48 hours at the whim of the oil company? Companies can move in and remodel or disrupt without compensation. Suddenly they may want to change the facade of a particular service station; so they move in. There is no compensation. There is no way the companies will discount the fuel or help people in some way. They can just move in and do it. These are conditions that lock people in 100 per cent with that company.

We have an Act of this Parliament that says that people have a right of choice. They have a choice of getting 50 per cent of their fuel from some other company. That has not worked because what the companies do, whichever flag flies, be it Shell or BP, is to come back and say, `All right, you have the right to buy it but you do not put it in the tanks that you are renting from us. You do not put it through the bowser that you are renting from us'. It is rather ridiculous to have that rule; but at least the rule is there. Some of these conditions that the companies are putting into these contracts waive that rule. There is no right of choice. The companies say that they want a business-like practice. They want an open or even playing field to give them all a fair go. But it seems that that fair go is lopsided when it comes to the retailer.

There are certainly tough rules when it comes to the transportation of fuel. I cited in this House once before, and I do it again to emphasise the point, that in my electorate I have a service station proprietor who has made it clear, and he has shown me on his books, that if he has the right to transport his own fuel out of Mackay or Rockhampton to his site-I will not name his site because of the risk of victimisation-and he transports that fuel some 300 kilometres, he will save 4c a litre. If he does it himself or gets an independent person to transport it, it will cost around 2c a litre to shift it. At the moment he is locked into the company and it is costing him 6c a litre.

The companies talk about fairness. They talk about wanting an entrepreneurial approach. They say that they want a fairer, more businesslike and more efficient approach. Let them start applying this. It is no wonder there are consumers and retailers throughout this nation saying, `Let us have 100 per cent divorcement of the oil companies from retailing. Let us get them out of that area. Then we will stop the problems with the jobbers. We will stop the rorts with the discounting. We will stop the over- bearing rules that they apply when it comes to franchise agreements and contracts. We will stop the unfair rules when it comes to the transportation of fuel'.

As I have said-and I reiterate this point-I understand why companies want to change some of the rules. They can get locked in for a nine-year period to a retailer who really has not got it and who does little service to himself, to the company or to his consumers. At the same time they have to consider the many other thousands of retailers who have invested in a business over a long period. At this moment they are under threat of losing everything that they have worked for, saved for and in most instances borrowed for.

I have seen the books of some retailers throughout Queensland. I have not had the chance to see those in other States, but certainly in Queensland some of these retailers have been forced to work on 2c a litre. That is not even enough money to service their loan and pay wages, let alone pay the rent. However, they are forced to work on this amount because of the discounting wars and the tactics that have been used by some companies. Companies using their own sites pick a site and pour fuel into it, especially a highway site, and down comes the price of fuel not just at that site but in the whole area. They bring down the price of fuel for 20, 30, 50 or 150 other sites because others have to compete. Those other sites are working on 2c or 3c a litre. It is no wonder they put people off.

Two years ago we carried out a survey in the northern parts of Brisbane and towards the Gold Coast. Working on just 25 sites we found a loss of almost 200 jobs. That was during the price war. They simply could not continue to employ those people. There has to be rationalisation. I accept that. There has to be common sense and fairness. There has to be equity. I suggest that this will come about only if the companies will sit down with the retailers and consumer groups and talk it through. I congratulate Esso. It took the initiative of coming to talk to me. I know that it is talking to the retailers and it is prepared to talk to consumer groups. I know that it is prepared, as Mobil is already doing, to work through the contracts with its retailers because some of the provisions that have been put forward have not been fair. Some are even unconscionable. Some work towards exclusive dealing under section 47 of the Trade Practices Act. Others even verge upon the monopoly provisions of the Trade Practices Act in section 46. If this is the way other companies are going to play the game, with this first to the line approach-either they cop it and sign on the dotted line, or else-this House has to do something about it.

At the moment we are in a mode of deregulation. We are saying, `Let us deregulate the marketplace to bring about greater efficiency'. I can understand that point of view. I have some concerns about it and I have said that before. I can understand it. But when we allow a deregulation mentality to send thousands of small business people to the wall, which costs tens of thousands of jobs, then we have to say `Stop'. I would say `Stop' in this instance. We have just one year to sort this issue out. I know that some companies are prepared to sort it out. Others are not. Other companies are playing it hard and tough right now. I give them a message. I send them a signal that there are many members on the Government side-as I know there are on the Opposition side because I have spoken to them-who are not going to wear it. We want a fair deal for the companies. We want them to have that degree of profitability that will allow them to continue to invest in this country and to explore and develop the oil industry, as the honourable member for Gippsland said. But we want a fair deal for dealers, the small business people. We want a fair deal for those millions of consumers who rely upon their product. This will come about only if there are fair agreements.

The companies have an obligation to consumers. They have an obligation to keep the prices at a competitive level. They have an obligation to keep competition in the system. I am not sure that competition has always prevailed. Therefore, I say to those companies: Let us have the discussion; let us have the dialogue. If that is not the outcome over the next few months then there has to be trouble. Many members of parliament will be arguing not only that we should return to those two Acts of Parliament but also that we should toughen them up, that we use the Trade Practices Commission to take on the rogues and the rebels in the oil companies in the interests of this nation, the retailers and the consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow two speakers on the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill. First of all I would like to compliment the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who has just been appointed a shadow Minister. I think that he has a good grasp of his shadow portfolio. I wish him the very best. Secondly, I do not disagree with anything the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said. Probably a lot of honourable members in here today-although, incidentally, there are not many honourable members in here at the moment-and a lot of people listening to the broadcast will be saying, `Oh, Bruce Goodluck. I hope that he does not make that speech he has made about 17 times before'. I know that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has ready the reply for Bruce Goodluck that we have the fourth cheapest petrol in the world. However, let me just say that, although we have the fourth cheapest petrol in the world, we are a very large continent. Those other countries that were referred to are very small. It does not take long to drive around them. Therefore, Australia is a little different.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Capricornia said, the oil industry is a vital industry. We could talk about how much money is being spent and how much money is being derived by way of taxation. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), today has talked about home care and home help. He knows, as I know, that we need money to provide that. If we are going to help the elderly of Australia we need money. That money has to be derived from taxes. We all understand that. However, we need to understand also that there are consumers; that there are people who worry about the variation in the price of petroleum from one place to another. We have allowed that variation to go on unabated.

The honourable member for Capricornia will remember quite well that I have said on a number of occasions over the last 13 years that we have set up committees to do certain things. I have said that we have Senate select committees to look into this and House of Representatives committees to look into that; but why do we not have a select committee to look at the oil industry, at the service station industry, to find out a bit about it? However, there are always reasons why we cannot do that. This is an industry that needs looking at. It is an industry that needs the concern of all members because it is such a vital and important industry.

I thought that I would refer to the report of the 1975 Collins Royal Commission on Petroleum. Commissioner Collins talked about liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) as a viable alternative. I did a survey, the results of which quite astounded me. I found that in Hobart the price of LPG is roughly 32c a litre; Canberra roughly 23c; Perth roughly 28c; and Victoria between 12c and 15c. I thought that here we have an alternative to petrol. In 1976 I wrote a few notes about that. I will repeat those points to get them into Hansard so that people will realise that LPG is an accepted fuel.

We have vast quantities of LPG in Australia; we know that there are problems with meeting the demand for oil. Therefore, we have the viable alternative of LPG. Cars, utilities, trucks and other vehicles can run, and do run, efficiently and economically on LPG. Vehicles run on LPG are easier to start. There are fewer oil changes, longer engine life and less mechanical attention to the engine. The use of LPG results in a greatly lower level of pollutants in the air. There is one grade of fuel with the use of LPG. LPG can be sold easily. We have talked about the rationalisation of the service station industry. We all know that the days of service at service stations are gone. We all know that, in the main, when one pulls into service stations today it is a case of self-serve. We have to realise that that is the trend and the way that the industry has gone. Service stations are selling points for many items. For example, we see loaves of bread and potatoes, anything we like to name, being sold at service stations. Why can all service stations not sell LPG to service the vehicles that come in?

People dislike change. I can understand that. There have been a few rumours about LPG which are completely untrue. Most of the taxis in Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra run on LPG. They run very economically and very efficiently on LPG. We can get optional engines, brakes, upholstery, differentials and gear boxes; why can we not have the option of LPG? I know that the Toyota company at one stage produced a motor vehicle that ran specifically on LPG. People do not like change. They worried that if they could not get LPG to fuel the vehicle they would be in strife. Now we have the dual fuel system that is used by most taxis and a lot of consumers in Australia also. The use of LPG is something we could look at very seriously if we tackled it in the right way. I believe that there is not enough dialogue and debate on this subject. Sometimes we get involved in issues that do not relate to the real consumers.

In talking about the price of fuel, I mention that that varies greatly around Australia. I listened to the remarks of the honourable member for Capricornia. I noted that he missed an important point. He did not refer to the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). That is an authority set up by the Government and funded by the taxpayers of Australia. I have been critical of the Authority in the past. If I had my way I would disband the Authority because I do not think it is able to do the job. We have the Labor State governments and their price watch committees, or whatever they call them, looking at the price of groceries, et cetera. Surely that is the job of the Prices Surveillance Authority? Surely if there is an excessive price for groceries in one part of Australia, we should know about it? However, I am afraid that the Prices Surveillance Authority has failed in the area of fuel pricing. I know that it is looking at the price of home heating oil now. It has not done that previously and as a consequence the price has varied from State to State. I have given a sound indication to honourable members that the Prices Surveillance Authority has no idea of the price of LPG. Of course, it has no idea of how to control the price of petrol.

Previously oil companies went individually to the Prices Surveillance Authority. A maximum wholesale price for petrol was fixed for every company. It varied, by not very much, between each company. Now, of course, the oil companies go together to the PSA. Now if they can hit on a price-which they do-that is called the maximum wholesale price. That is the price that does not vary very much from one part of Australia to another. That is the price that is charged. I do not want to be too critical of the oil companies. They provide sound employment opportunities for many people in Australia. Their investment in Australia is immense. They do many fine things for the economy of Australia. I think that the taxation derived from oil companies is about $9 billion, so it would be a futile exercise just to criticise the oil companies. However, the marketing practices of some oil companies leave a lot to be desired. I believe that they should be the subject of an inquiry. We have had inquiries before; for example, the Collins Royal Commission. However, that did not amount to very much because those recommendations really were not put into place.

It was mentioned today that the oil companies are going for rack prices. I really do not understand that. It sounds very complicated. It has been indicated to me that there is a fixed wholesale price and everybody buys petrol at that fixed price. However, theoretically that is really the situation at the moment. That really does not work. I really do not know what the oil companies are about in that regard. It is something that needs to be studied.

The argument is always put to me that Tasmania has the highest petroleum price in Australia. We have; petrol costs 65c a litre. The State Government imposes a 7c a litre tax to make up for the lack of funds from the Federal Government. We could have a double argument on that. Petrol is dear for the consumers of Tasmania. Most people do not realise that since the Hawke Government came to power the wholesale price of petrol has gone up between 10c and 13c a litre. I often think of one of the famous points made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during an election campaign when he said that the Government would reduce the price of petrol by 2c a litre. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that it was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump. However, they know, and we know, that if we are going to fund programs in Australia we need money. It is a very easy way to extract money from the consumers of Australia, particularly in Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney. Every time we fill our cars up we are paying for some project in Australia, so everybody should have a fair, sensible and balanced opportunity to use our very precious resource; that is, petrol.

I refer again to LPG. I would like every Commonwealth car in Australia to use LPG. It would not be a very difficult problem. I would like all taxis-and they probably are-to use LPG. I would also like governments to give consumers the inducement, by some form of taxation, to transfer to LPG.
