SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), which gives effect to a series of decisions made by the Government in recent months. First of all, it removes the exemption that government business enterprises had from excises. Secondly, it makes the six-monthly adjustment to the excise on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG)-a subject very close to the heart of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)-and, thirdly, it removes the exercise on aviation kerosene.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say-if I may just interpolate another matter-that the public address systems we get in country halls in my own electorate are substantially better than the one we have in the $1 billion national Parliament. I hope that we can make that great technological breakthrough sooner or later and make sure that we have a proper loudspeaker system in this chamber.

Let me begin with the issue of government business enterprises and the decision of the Government to remove the exemption from excise that those business enterprises have. We on this side of the House generally support a level playing field for government business enterprises. We want government business enterprises to operate in a competitive environment, and they should be treated in a similar manner to their private sector counterparts. That is particularly true where those government business enterprises compete directly with the private sector, as does the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Where they are a monopoly, perhaps it is another matter. It is important that the Government's enterprises compete in a fair manner with the private sector.

In the past, public sector business organisations have been substantially advantaged through favourable taxation treatment and the like. We on this side of the House believe that the reform of government business enterprises is long overdue. The removal of the excise exemptions will impact quite substantially on the Government business enterprises' operating costs. of course, it will lead to an increase in prices-there is no question of that. Already Australia Post and Telecom Australia have announced price increases in both postage stamps and telephone charges respectively. Stamps have gone up from 37c to 39c, local telephone calls have increased from 20c to 21c, and other business charges are also up. Business enterprises are passing on to the general community these increased charges flowing from the removal of the excise exemptions. For us on this side of the House it is a matter of very real regret that the Hawke Government, over its 5 1/2 years, has treated government business enterprises in exactly the same way as the Wran Government did in New South Wales-as milch cows for increasing government revenue.

It is interesting to note the submission made by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) recently to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry on government taxes and charges, in particular in relation to Telecom and Australia Post costs. Let me cite the percentage of respondents to the CAI survey of its members who classified Telecom and Australia Post costs as important to their overall corporate costs. It is interesting to note that 50 per cent said that Telecom costs had a direct and important bearing-not a peripheral bearing, but an important bearing-on the overall costs of their enterprises and that 34 per cent of respondents to the CAI's survey made the same point about Australia Post charges. It is interesting to note that, over the period during which the CAI survey was taken, Telecom charges had increased by a massive 59 per cent and postal charges by 57 per cent. That was over a period of a few years-a substantial increase above the rate of inflation.

When we look at the response of members of the business community as to how they really feel about the service they are getting for, by their standards, such an exorbitant cost, it is clear that very few think that they are getting a particularly good service. I point out that 22 per cent of respondents to the survey said that Telecom was providing them with a low quality of service and 26 per cent claimed that Australia Post was providing them with a low quality of service. They are matters of real concern and they are matters that the Government needs to address, particularly at a time when through this legislation and other legislation it is trying to make Telecom, Australia Post and other government enterprises more commercial and, if you like, more competitive.

My concern is that the Government's motive is not so much to reform government business enterprises, but to collect as much tax revenue from them as it possibly can. It is more greed on the part of the Government, which wants to build up its Budget surplus to as great an extent as possible and continue with its overall philosophical commitment to extracting as much as it can from the general community into the coffers of government. Ultimately it is the consumers who will feel the effects of that.

The Government has removed and is removing other taxation exemptions, particularly in relation to Australia Post and Telecom. These include local government taxes, rates and charges, customs duty, sales tax, income tax, and various other miscellaneous taxes. In the context of organisational constraints, whilst the Government has moved to try to make these organisations more competitive, it has to be said that there are still three major issues that remain unresolved as far as the Government's so-called blueprint for government business enterprises is concerned. The first of those constraints relates to the role of the Loan Council. The Loan Council still provides global borrowing limits for government business enterprises and clearly that imposes, therefore, on those business enterprises a commercial constraint which at times, in the judgment of the enterprises, may be deleterious.

Certainly, if the Government were serious about making government business enterprises bona fide, genuine business enterprises, it would not place those sorts of constraints on those enterprises. Those constraints act as a severe inhibition on the ability of government business enterprises, for example, to determine their most appropriate debt-equity ratios. That acts to distort the investment patterns of those enterprises. If one looks at the record of Australian National Railways over the last 10 years it is really quite alarming to see how the debt-equity ratio has changed so substantially in favour of debt. The fact that equity has declined is a matter of real concern to me. There are many reasons for that, not all of them directly associated with this legislation. The simple fact is that good business enterprises are very much suffering from a lack of proper commercial opportunity which an ordinary company in the private sector might have.

The second organisational constraint that government business enterprises face is that the Government has yet to define exactly what the new superannuation arrangements will be for government business enterprises. Details of those arrangements will not be known until March-April next year following a review of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme presently being conducted by the Department of Finance. Obviously, the review must take place. We hope that the review comes to satisfactory and intelligent conclusions which ensure that government business enterprises operate in a truly commercial way. There has been enormous concern, particularly in the context of the debate on privatisation, about the issue of unfunded superannuation. The Government is addressing this issue, which must be addressed and must be resolved as soon as possible.

The third constraint is that the Government has failed to follow through on its so-called privatisation agenda. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched a privatisation debate within the Labor Party. People such as Senator Evans, Senator Button and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) supported that privatisation debate. Amassed against them have been the left wing in particular and other backbenchers-indeed, some frontbenchers such as the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West)-of the Labor Party who are ideologically opposed to a greater role for private enterprises in the provision of services to ordinary Australians.

It is well known that we, on this side of the House, believe that many of the existing government business enterprises should be privatised. We believe that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, the Australian Industry Development Commission, and so on should be privatised. We support privatisation of those government business enterprises not because we are on some sort of ideological crusade or because we want to privatise for the sake of privatising-as the left wing, indeed most, of the Labor Party argue-but on the contrary because we want to ensure that consumers of the goods and services provided by those government business enterprises are provided for in the most efficient way and at the most competitive price. If one maintains monopolies or special privileges for government business enterprises, one will not get the best possible price for consumers and one will not maximise efficiency in what are now government business enterprises. As Senator Evans and the Prime Minister know only too well, but do not have the political authority successfully to persuade their Party, the losers are ordinary Australian consumers.

Wherever there are monopolies there are winners. There are people who benefit from monopoly rents or special privilege rents that come from some of the special privileges that government business enterprises are able to obtain. In Eastern Europe the special privileges, the monopoly rents, are collected by the bureaucracy-the political apparatchiks of the dominant political parties. In countries such as those of Latin America and, indeed, some parts of Asia the same sorts of monopolies exist. The monopoly rents are collected by a very small handful of families who put the money into their pockets and are able accumulate enormous wealth. As a result of that, there is a gigantic diversity between wealth and poverty in so many of those countries.

In Australia we too, through our government business enterprises, have a number of similar sorts of monopolies. But, of course, in our society it would be understandably regarded as outrageous for the monopoly rents to be pocketed by a very small number of individuals. What in fact happens is that the monopoly rents are absorbed through business inefficiency and through restrictive work practices promoted by the trade union leadership in some of those enterprises. That is what happens to monopoly rents in business enterprises of that sort in Australia which have uncompetitive monopolies. Again, it is the consumers who provided that monopoly rent to the Government-in this case the bureaucracy which runs these enterprises. We, on this side of the House, could never support that sort of system.

From historical experience over 200 to 300 years, we know, as anybody who has an interest in economic history knows, that at the end of the day the only way we will disburse monopoly rents and ensure that a proper and competitive price structure is provided through the maximisation of business efficiency is through competition. If we do not have competition we will have monopoly, and if we have a monopoly, as sure as night follows day-to use the famous phrase of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)-monopoly rents will be collected. The consumer-the ordinary Australian man or woman who consumes goods and services provided by these enterprises-will be the loser. So many people in the leadership-if that is what one could call it-of the Government know this but they cannot deliver; they fail to deliver. A change of government is the only way this will be delivered.

Government business enterprises are only one part of this legislation. Very briefly, for the record, I will touch on the other two parts. First, there is a provision in this legislation to make a six monthly adjustment to excise on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). We have already had a bit of a debate in the chamber today on LPG and I will not enlarge too substantially on that. I just say that the six monthly adjustment to excise is basically a boomerang tax-it comes back and hits a person every six months. There is something pernicious about that, but then, as it comes from a government which lives and breathes for taxation, one should not be surprised. We must not destroy our very profitable and very successful LPG industry with a continually growing taxation burden on that industry. It is worth remembering that the LPG industry earns about $270m a year in export income. As the honourable member for Franklin said a little earlier, 84 per cent of those exports go to Japan, where much of the LPG is used in commercial transport.

What is, and should be, of concern to all Australians is the prediction coming from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics which suggests that by the year 2000 the export revenue we will be able to obtain from LPG will fall from $270m per annum to $96m per annum in 1986 dollar terms. Who knows whether that prediction is accurate? Those sorts of predictions are coming forward all the time in the mineral and resources area. We know that some of them have proved to be hopelessly wrong. In my experience, I have often found them to be more pessimistic than they need to be. But it does underline the fact that this is a very strong and viable industry and one which, in the longer term, does not have very strong prospects. It is a mistake to try to throttle these industries by extracting as much tax as is humanly possible from them. They have to be viable and profitable, and that is a message that the Government needs to understand.

The third aspect of this legislation is the removal of the duty on aviation kerosene. Because we on this side of the House believe in lower taxes, in relief from duties and charges, in smaller government and more viable enterprise, naturally we are glad that the Government has decided to remove the duty on aviation kerosene. It is being replaced by an en route charge levied by the Civil Aviation Authority on aircraft flying between different locations. I think that is a much more efficient way of, if you like, imposing a charge on the general aviation industry in particular for the cost of services provided by airports. Clearly, a system such as the Government is introducing will be a user pays system. That is, if someone decides to fly between two airports, he pays a charge which relates to the use of services at those airports. Before, when that money was raised through duty on aviation kerosene, the reality was that the further a person flew, the more duty he paid, obviously because he has used more fuel to fly the greater distance yet he may not have been using more services. It is the number of landings that above all determines the use of services rather than the sheer distance which he flies. This is a rational and intelligent measure taken by the Government.

I know there is some concern in the aviation industry about the imposition of the en route charge which is being levied by the Government. The details of that will have to be resolved over time, but I hope that system will settle down and those concerns will gradually be dismissed. The fact is that this is a more rational system and one that we, on this side of the House, very warmly welcome.

In conclusion, the Opposition does not oppose the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). We hope that the Government, in responding to this debate, will take note in particular of some of the concerns we have about the administration and management of government business enterprises, because at the end of the day the Prime Minister, and Senator Gareth Evans in particular, know that what we have been saying for years about government business enterprises is right, and that the opposition that is arrayed against the Government from its back benches in particular, but from some of the Ministry, including no doubt the Minister at the table, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), is ideological opposition and not rational opposition. It is opposition based on sentiment of the great nationalisation program of people such as Chifley rather than on the reality of providing ordinary Australians with a better deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) brings into action another commitment made by the Government in the 1988 May economic statement. It removes the exemption from liability for excise duty afforded to government business enterprises. The Government has decided that all government enterprises should be exposed to the same taxes and charges as private businesses. Therefore, all Commonwealth agencies now liable for customs duty on their imports will be liable for excise duty from 1 July 1989 on domestically produced accessible goods which they use. Government business enterprises subject to customs duties but exempt from excise duties include Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Both organisations will also be liable for State and local government taxes, rates and charges with effect from 1 July 1989. From the 1990-91 income year both will be subject to income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of these exemptions is designed to improve the efficiency of government business enterprises by placing them on a more commercial footing and I think that is only right and proper. The enterprises need, more than ever before, flexibility and the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to take up opportunities as they present themselves. Under revised arrangements, there will be requirements for corporate plans and the setting of financial targets and this will allow the Government to focus on `bottom line' results rather than central controls over managerial decision making. Efficient government business enterprises have the ability, through returns to the Budget in the form of dividends as well as their pursuit of national or other objectives, to contribute in a major way to the common good of all Australians.

In the past, government organisations have had controls relating to borrowings, executive remuneration, industrial relations coordination and superannuation arrangements. Governments have loaded enterprises with controls which their competitors do not have and which I believe constitute barriers to efficiency, including restrictive controls on management operations, restrictive capital raising policies and poor board appointments.

In the case of Australia Post, controls have resulted in cumbersome administrative processes and delays as the necessary approvals by various arms of the Government are sought. The Government has announced new guidelines for government business enterprises and statutory authorities. The setting of appropriate financial targets will remove the need for some of the more specific detailed controls. Within Australia Post, competition already exists for a number of the Commission's services, the main competitive areas being parcels, agency courier delivery and bulk-householder-mail. Opening the standard letter monopoly to external competition, I believe, would have adverse implications for the community service obligations undertaken by Australia Post. It would surely harm the ability to provide uniform price structure.

Australia Post has faced a significant increase in competition over the past 10 to 15 years. This has had a positive effect on the attitudes of Australia Post and its management. Certain aspects of its work are open to competitive bidding. Roadside mail delivery services in outer urban and rural electorates are contracted out after competitive bidding. Of the 4,537 post offices, 3,145 are operated by private sector businesses under contract. Competition in Australia Post is already there. This Bill enables the organisation to be exposed to further charges faced by other businesses.

Telecom as an organisation has faced a range of controls over its affairs. It is restricted by Loan Council requirements, which reduce the flexibility of management in financing decisions. However, the freeing up of this requirement would not necessarily address the underlying problem. The need to focus on efficiency, modernisation and participation in a range of future ventures may well mean more debt per capita, not less. Technological advances such as digitisation and fibre optics provide a massive increase in the telecommunications network capacity and efficiency with lower unit costs. Updating of the network requires greater capital expenditure compared to simply replacing or adding capacity to old technology infrastructure. To date, with world developments, in some areas like the integrated services digital network, electronic funds transfer and QPSX-a joint venture company with the University of Western Australia set up to develop new telecommunications switching technology-Australia is among the world leaders.

There is already competition in some sections of Telecom's business, particularly in the faster growing areas. This competition will increase in the future even without formal regulatory change. The commercial capacity of Telecom to participate advantag- eously will be mentioned if it is given the ability to stand the changes forced on it by measures in this Bill. Like Australia Post, Telecom will face the same taxes and charges as other businesses. Both organisations will then compete with business on a level playing field.

The third aspect of the Bill is the reduction of excise duty on aviation kerosene and substituting an en route charge levied by the Civil Aviation Authority. This was the subject of a brief flurry of media releases by Queensland's Minister for Transport, Mr Gibbs. Mr Gibbs apparently believed that the increases for airlines in my electorate would be about 30 per cent. The only way Mr Gibbs could have arrived at this inflated figure was for him or his Department to add every increase. Instead, the increase was a 3 per cent increase over previous charging arrangements. Honourable members now have some appreciation of why the Queensland Budget Papers have many large photos, a few words and almost no figures. A group called Flight West Airlines also berated the Government over the increase. The airline in fact threatened not to pay the new charges. In reality, at that time, the airline had not paid charges levied by the Department of Transport and Communications in the financial year which ended on 30 June 1988.

The new Civil Aviation Authority has been established by the Government to take over operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems and rescue and fire fighting services at airports.

The major variations to charging arrangements include the introduction of en route charges for avtur fuelled aircraft to replace budgetary revenues from avtur fuel excise and departure tax. SPEECH.PARA: The changed arrangements ensure that CAA is fully responsible and accountable for the provision and pricing of its commercial airways services. TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-On behalf of the Government I wish to respond to a couple of points that were made. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) raised the question of the proposed increase in the excise rate for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), which is contained in clause 3 of the Bill. While the excise rate is indeed to be increased from $13.21 to $15.39 per kilolitre from 1 April 1988, it is important to note that the increase is not the result of any change in the Government's LPG policy-that is, it is not, as the honourable member suggested, a means for the Government to extract more revenue from industry. In fact, the formula by which the excise rate is determined has not changed since April 1980, when the previous Government's formula, continued by this Government, was announced.

SPEECH.PARA: The excise rate is set at 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne, expressed as a rate per kilolitre. The realised price is calculated as a weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the most recent six months. For the 1 April 1988 adjustment, this was the period 1 September 1987 to 29 February 1988. The increase in the excise rate from 1 April in this Bill from $13.21 to $15.39 per kilolitre reflects higher export prices during that period.

Just as the rate might go up in times of high export prices, so too might it go down. The honourable member might recall that in the Excise Tariff Act 1987, for instance, the excise rate on LPG decreased from $50.77 per kilolitre in October 1986 to $5.02 per kilolitre on 1 April 1987. This was the direct result of the application of the same formula to the lower export prices that applied. I note in this regard that the net result was an estimated reduction in revenue of about $50m.

I want to thank honourable members generally for their contributions to the debate. A number of questions were also raised about the charges affecting government business enterprises (GBEs) and whether increased charges will result-especially Telecom Australia and Australia Post charges. In this regard the honourable member for Mayo noted that Telecom and Australia Post announced increases in their charges. While this may be true, those increases cannot be said to result from the measures announced in this Bill, since these measures do not begin until 1 July 1989.

The removal of remaining exemptions for Commonwealth business enterprises is expected to result in increased revenue of about $25m per annum from 1989-90 in relation to the following: the ACT Electricity Authority, the Australian National Railways Commission, the Australian Postal Commission, the Civil Aviation Authority, the Federal Airports Corporation and Telecom. The amendment is part of a package to improve their efficiency by making them face a full range of taxes and charges. Any increase in charges by these bodies would serve only to blunt their competitive edge. That is the thrust of the Government's strategy.

Finally, I would like to make a comment about government business enterprises and the Loan Council. The honourable member for Mayo also suggested that Loan Council restrictions should cease to apply to government business enterprises if they were to become truly competitive. The Government will, of course, examine all matters to further its strategy to make GBEs more competitive. However, as this measure affects the Government's monetary policy, it is perhaps more appropriate that the matter be referred to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh).

In respect of Loan Council controls on authority borrowings, the Government has taken a number of steps to place Commonwealth government business enterprises on a more commercial basis. However, these enterprises still differ from private businesses because they are able to borrow funds for investment on the basis of the Government's ultimate backing for the enterprise and many, including Telecom and Australia Post, have community service obligations to provide non-commercial services. This means that, in the absence of quantitative controls on borrowing, they could borrow more freely and be prepared to accept lower rates of return than would comparable private businesses. The Loan Council controls are administered flexibly, having regard to the capital requirements of the enterprises as well as broader economic considerations. This is evidenced by the fact that borrowings by Commonwealth authorities will be allowed to double in 1988-89 to $2.6 billion with the increase being primarily to meet the need for capital expenditure in the aviation industry. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It suits the convenience of the Government to conduct the debate in this fashion and the Opposition is more than happy to oblige. There are many important matters before the House tonight. Mr Acting Speaker, I would like to begin by saying that this package of Bills underlines the Government's confusion about what to do about government business enterprises. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) know what they would like to do and I think the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) supports them. What they would like to do is sell a lot of them. But there are certain sections in the Australian Labor Party who do not think that is a good idea. So, to the extent that those Ministers can sort of edge along the track, they are converting some government enterprises to public companies. If they get the numbers on a good day or if they get the courage on an even better day these government business enterprises will be in a format which will enable them to be sold off. But this is, as I said, an example of the confusing and inconsistent approach of the Government to this area of government activity that in most cases would be well handled by the private sector. Not only would it be well handled but it would be more efficiently handled and with less burden on the Australian taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: We are discussing a number of Bills here tonight. I intend to address my remarks to them individually and then make some concluding remarks about the whole package. The first Bill I would like to discuss is the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. The Government would dearly like to sell the Australian National Line (ANL), but it cannot quite get the idea through Caucus or its national convention. The best it can do is to convert ANL to a public company and talk about how that will make it far more efficient. The truth of the matter is that it will not do much. It will change some of the operating constraints that apply to it and push it out into the marketplace a bit further, but it will make it a little easier for ANL to be sold at some time in the future. The Opposition certainly welcomes that, because its policy is to sell ANL to its employees and to the Australian public.

At a later time in this debate we will be moving an amendment to the effect that, while we would not oppose this Bill, we are disappointed that the Government has not proceeded at a more rapid rate with what is known in technical terms or political jargon as micro-economic reform. That is a euphemism for making people work a little more effectively and efficiently in this sector of the economy. Anybody who has any experience with coastal shipping or the waterfront in Australia knows that it is a classic example of a highly protected sector of the economy where there is precious little competition between the participants and absolutely none from outside.

One way to achieve a bit of competition, a bit of efficiency, a bit of market generated allocation of resources, would be to have some competition from overseas. The policy of the Liberal and National parties is to introduce that competition, particularly to coastal shipping. We would do it by allowing Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) ships to trade on the Australian coast. That is the way to do it. At present the Australian flagships have a total monopoly of Australian coastal shipping. Because of that monopoly, there is not a great incentive to operate more efficiently. We need a little outside pressure. I am not talking about bringing in ships that are poorly manned and have substandard safety regulations; I am talking about bringing ships from comparable countries, OECD countries, and applying a bit of healthy marketplace pressure to the present operators. If the Government had any real commitment to the Australian taxpayer and any real commitment to our industries that are dependent upon efficient shipping and low cost transport, it would be doing likewise.

The Prime Minister has been wandering around the country in recent weeks telling everybody who will listen in various forums that there is no need to worry because he has fixed the coastal shipping and waterfront problem. I guess he rang the Minister for Transport and Communications from time to time and said, `Hurry up, Ralph. We desperately need a quick fix for this because I am raising expectations left, right and centre'. The fact of the matter is that the Government has been in power for 5 1/2 years and does not have any stomach to come to grips with this important question affecting our economy. It has a flow-on effect, also, on other forms of transport. Coastal shipping in Australia has become so expensive in recent years that people have walked away from it in droves. The only things that travel by ship around the Australian coast now are things that cannot go any other way. If one needs to move goods in this country one will do anything one can to make sure they do not go on a ship, because there has to be a cheaper way of doing it. Of course, that has had a distorting effect on our railway system and our road transport system.

The Bill I will address next relates to the Australian National Railways Commission. This Bill does not deal with a conversion to a public company, because the Government is not quite sure what it will do with Australian National. I think it would like to privatise some of the lines-that is, sell them, lease them or lease time slots for operation on the lines-but it is not quite sure how to handle it. The Government has not addressed the massive problem of picking up the losses on State rail operations either. That represents about $3 billion a year. Imagine how the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance would like to get their hands on that $3 billion. It would be $3 billion less to the States if those railway systems operated more efficiently.

Not only does the Government have the dilemma of privatisation or how to stop the losses of State rail systems but also it has the problem of what to do with the Western Australian railway system. It does not quite know whether to stick its toe in the water there and grab another railway network, as it did in Tasmania, or to stay well away from it. That underlines the confusion and the policy paralysis that exist within the Government at present. It has been in power for 5 1/2 years and it still does not know what to do about these problems. It has been looking at them at close range and it has had the benefit of departmental advice as to the problems and their legislative solutions but we still do not see any decisive action.

We do not see a comprehensive approach to transport in this country. We still see piecemeal legislation. We still see it in communications as well. The whole area of transport and communications, including aviation, is an example of piecemeal, ad hoc policy, driven by partisan considerations and what the factions will allow the Government to do from time to time, depending upon which way the wind is blowing and how they think the opinion polls are standing up. It is not in the best interests of this country, it is not in the best interests of the taxpayers-the people who use the network-and it is certainly operating to the detriment of our standard of living.

I said that I would talk about these Bills roughly in the order in which they appear on the Notice Paper. For the sake of consistency, I skipped over the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. I have dealt with the Australian National Line legislation, which is about shipping, and I have made some remarks about the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill, but the one in the middle which I deliberately skipped over is the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. This again is an example of the Government going only halfway to where it would like to go.

The Liberal and National parties know exactly what they would like to do with the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC). It is a quite profitable operation. There is no real need for it to be government-owned as long as we have the right controls over who owns it and what it does. We welcome its conversion to a public company. We challenge the Government to take the next step; that is, to sell it. It could sell 49 per cent in the first stage and see how it goes, then move to 100 per cent. That is what we would do. We would privatise it. I suggest that the Government grasp the nettle and do what it has to do. Then it might be able to use the money it gets to repay some of the massive debt load that it has incurred for this country in recent years. As I said, there is absolutely no reason, apart from the restraints within the Australian Labor Party, why the Government should not go the whole hog.

I wonder how the left wing feels when it sees Bills such as these coming into the House. It knows what is one the agenda. It is not even a hidden agenda. Blind Freddy can see what the Minister for Finance, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have up their sleeves. They know that they are saying, `Convert it to a public company until we have the numbers and the left wing is not looking because it is more concerned with defending the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, perhaps'. By golly, he really needs defending at present; he had a bad day today. We can bet that, when the left wing is not looking, the right wing will privatise these companies. Of course, that is what should happen. For how much longer will the left wing sit quietly by and allow this to happen? We have seen it with ANL. I wonder when the seamen will start putting on a bit of pressure; when we will see some open factional warfare over this matter.

I wonder when OTC will be sold. It must be very tempting for a Treasurer who is framing an election year Budget and is under all the pressure in the world to come up with massive tax cuts because expectations have been built up to look at OTC and think, `We could probably sell that. That would give me a bit more of a cash flow. We have sold the embassies in Tokyo and Paris'. Let me say that we did not get a very good deal in Paris. Have honourable members heard what the real estate agents are saying about the price we got for the Paris property? It is a bit of a joke. Someone ought to have a good, hard look at it.

Privatisation is certainly on the agenda, but the Australian Labor Party will not come clean. It will not address this matter within its Caucus or within its conference. It is not game to take it back to the branches because, as everybody knows, it is way out of touch with its traditional supporters. The traditional supporters do not like the idea of selling off enterprises such as these as they provide a rather featherbed occupation for many people. But the Australian taxpayer has had enough. We cannot afford to waste valuable resources on sponsoring and funding government business enterprises that would be quite willingly supported and funded by the private sector.

There are more glaring examples than the ones we are talking about tonight. Related government enterprises in this portfolio area are desperately crying out to be privatised. Their management is screaming for them to be privatised. For example, Qantas Airways Ltd needs to spend about $6 billion on acquiring an expanded jet fleet. To do that, it needs a capital injection of about $600m. The Government cannot afford to provide that. Of course, Australian Airlines is in exactly the same position. Of course, the Government will not address that problem. We saw the debate resurface the other day when the Minister for Transport and Communications said that the Government was looking at creative ways of financing these enterprises, and then the Minister for Finance piped up that perhaps one way to do it would be to sell off part of them.

So we can see what is on the agenda. This is just the forerunner of what will happen. It may happen in a May economic statement next year, or we might have to wait until the Budget itself. But we will hear an announcement that circumstances have changed, the Left has gone quiet and the Government can get a good price-and off will go OTC and ANL. By then maybe a couple of others will have got on to the agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. You can do better than this. What about the cross-subsidy?
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. I do appreciate your protection. That is exactly what will happen on the Government's agenda. Yet Government members have the hide to wander around the place saying that they will not do it. Of course, there is nothing surer; that is precisely what will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go back to the Australian National Line and discuss for a few moments the imperative to do something about this sector of our economy. Everybody is talking about it, including the Government's own instrumentalities. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) brought down an excellent and comprehensive report. It has several parts to it. I did not bring the second volume into the chamber tonight. It makes very interesting reading, but I will not try to read it into Hansard. I will just read the findings of the IAC report concerning Australian coastal shipping. Honourable members will understand why we are critical of the Government's failure to act in this area. The report says:
. . . the Commission has made the following findings in respect of coastal shipping in Australia.

I will paraphrase the first finding. It says that our coastal shipping `remains inefficient and uncompetitive relative to those in maritime nations with similar standards of living'-and, of course, that is the OECD countries that I was talking about. The only way we will put any competitive pressure on the Australian coastal shipping industry is to expose it to competition from OECD nations. The second finding is:

Major inefficiencies (both on-board and on-shore) manifest themselves in the form of excessive costs and avoidable delays which erode the international competitiveness of Australian industries and jeopardise growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy.

I was talking about the impact of this inefficiency on the Australian economy. Honourable members may think it relates directly only to those people who are forced to use coastal shipping. But it has a flow-on effect to all transport costs right around the country and, of course, it has an impact on the general price level-the costs of buying things at Woolworths, Coles or any other shop. Transport in Australia is more expensive than it has to be because no-one will act to improve its efficiency. For that reason, everybody pays a higher price. It is the Australian voter and taxpayer who is picking up the tab for these inefficiencies. That is why it is imperative for a government-one that really was in touch; one that was not arrogant and was concerned about the good stewardship of this nation-to act to do something about the maritime industry. The third finding of the IAC was:

The Commission estimates that if international freight rates applied on the coast then coastal shipping freight rates covering the ship- and shore-based segments of the industry would, on average, be between 20 and 50 per cent lower in most years. This would yield a direct saving of between $180 million and $460 million on the costs of freight services (on a wharfgate-to-wharfgate basis). When the flow on effects on the rest of the economy are taken into account, Australia's real gross domestic product could increase by between $250 million and $550 million per year in 1986-87 dollars.

That is in last year's dollars. Our rate of inflation under the Treasurer is fairly high these days, so one could add probably another 6 or 7 per cent to that. If that is the compound rate of benefit that we would get from addressing this inefficiency, we can see that it is an important thing to do.

Perhaps people do not understand the importance of doing this. We have one sector of the economy that is not subject to competitive pressure. Yet the Government is hell bent on opening up the rest of the economy to the pressure of the international marketplace. One sector of the economy that in recent years and months has become susceptible to that pressure is, of course, the sugar industry. But what the Government has not said is that sugar is grown on the east coast and a fair amount of it is consumed on the west coast; it is normally transported around there by ship. Our coastal shipping rates are so high that, as a result of the removal of the embargo on the importation of sugar, it is likely that the west coast market for sugar in Australia will be lost to the Australian sugar industry because it will be cheaper to bring sugar in from somewhere else on overseas shipping than to move Australian sugar around the coast on Australian coastal shipping. That is the impact that this little featherbedding deal has on the Australian industry and the Australian consumer. Something has to be done about it. It is not good enough for the Prime Minister to walk around the country talking about how he will act; it is important that something be done-and done very quickly.
I was going through the findings in the report of the IAC. The next one is:
The total benefits to the economy would be much larger than the above estimates suggest because they make no allowance for:
- the substantial costs of avoidable delays-

of course, that is a nice way of saying `strikes on the waterfront'. We all know about those. Things have got better in recent years, but what the wharfies and the people who man the Australian coastal shipping sector do to the efficiency of transport in this country is still absolutely horrific. The IAC says, further, that no allowance is made for:
- opportunities for further processing of raw materials in Australia; and
- the benefits that could arise from rationalising domestic production and distribution.
The next point made by the IAC is:

High costs and a poor record of service have progressively reduced the industry to a position where the only goods currently shipped around the coast tend to be those for which alternative transport modes are either not available or are not a realistic proposition.

As I said, the only people who use coastal shipping in Australia are those who cannot escape from it. If they can move their goods any other way they will do it, rather than having to confront the difficulties of using the Australian coastal shipping service. The next point is:

A more efficient coastal shipping industry would attract potential users who presently use alternative transport modes and pay more than they would if competitive coastal shipping services were available.
Of course, that again is a damning indictment of this Government's failure to act over the past 5 1/2 years. Three more such points are made in the IAC report. It says:
Inefficiencies which currently characterise the industry have developed in an environment which imposes little discipline on costs, fails to reward better performance and stifles initiative.

Of course, that finding alludes to the fact that one simply cannot compete on the Australian shipping routes unless one meets the unreasonable demands of the Australian unions-and, of course, no-one has ever done it. No-one has ever taken the option of bringing in a ship from overseas and complying. Some specific voyage permits have been issued from time to time, but no-one is bringing in overseas flagged ships and complying with our rules and regulations. There is an absolute barrier to competition. This Government says it believes in competition and deregulation and cries from the rooftops how market-oriented it is. It has not even got within cooee of addressing the problems in this sector of the economy. The next finding in the report is:
The major factors accounting for this outcome are the effective exclusion of competition from foreign-flag vessels under the Navigation Act-
we even have legislation that bolsters this little monopoly-
combined with a number of other regulatory and institutional factors both at sea and on-shore (including restrictive union practices).

That is just the unions using their muscle to reinforce their work practices, which you and I and everybody else who pays tax in this country are funding at present. The last point that the IAC makes is:

Real and lasting benefits will only be achieved if competitive influences are allowed to operate in both the sea-based and shore-based segments of the industry; to pursue further reform at sea without effectively addressing reform on the waterfront would be an exercise in futility.

From these remarks of the IAC we can see that there is only one option available to the Government, and that is to adopt the policy of the Liberal and National parties-to adopt the Opposition's policy and introduce a bit of competition to the waterfront, to make sure that we do in fact reduce the charges confronted by people who are forced to trade on the Australian coast and to do everything possible to overcome that inefficiency. It could be done on a gradual basis, but the Government should lay down a program and a set timetable that everybody has to work for-and not offer remission. It should not make the mistakes that it made with the car plan. It should not underwrite the profits of General Motors and Ford. It should not price the products of the industry out of the reach of the average family. That is what is done so often by this Government when it addresses an industry plan. It brings in an industry plan that has no restraint on it, no pressure on the industry to comply with it and no ceiling on the price levels; it just underwrites the profits. There would not be a member of the Labor Party who is not embarrassed by what the car plan has done in this country. It has not achieved rationalisation to any major extent. It has not achieved the efficiencies that we were promised. What it has achieved is the fact that the average Australian family can no longer afford to buy a Holden or a Falcon. Car prices went through the roof under the Button car plan.

Much the same thing happened in the steel industry. The steel industry was in crisis and the Government went charging to the rescue. A lot of money was involved and a great deal did not get to where it was supposed to go. It certainly did not achieve the situation for the Australian steel industry that we were promised when the steel plan was introduced. There was a lot of talk, rhetoric and posturing. What this Government is about is convincing people-the casual observer; perhaps the taxpayer who only sees his Government's policy on the television screen at night-that it is addressing the problems. In fact, it is not doing so. The Government is about window dressing-a facade, with no effective decision-making. It is not making hard decisions or decisions which might benefit the country in the medium and long terms. It is just making decisions which have an impact on the ballot box from time to time.

The test, and it is a test that has been set for the Government by itself, is coastal shipping. As I said when I began my speech, the Prime Minister has been wandering around the country talking to everybody-the people involved in industry, manufacturing and the chambers of commerce-saying, and I am fairly accurate as I paraphrase him, `Don't worry. We've got it fixed. We'll fix the coastal shipping problem and we will fix it quickly'. What he really means is that he has been working with some of his ministerial mates in the backroom to come up with a package that perhaps looks good but will not really address the problems. Anything short of introducing competition from outside to ensure efficiency and adherence to efficiency within the industry is inadequate. It is absolutely essential that this Government come to grips with the place of the market in this sector of the economy. If it is good enough to talk about financial deregulation, to expose the farm sector to international competition and to start reducing tariff barriers, it is also good enough to start reducing the barriers to competition within this sector of the economy. Before moving on to other sections of this cognate debate, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(1) notes the failure of the Government to achieve micro-economic reform in coastal shipping and the Australian waterfront; and

(2) calls on the Government to immediately introduce a program to increase the efficiency of coastal shipping, including the introduction of ships from OECD countries and other measures to overcome the problems identified by the IAC in its report and the Business Council of Australia, in its action plan'.

I reiterate that this cognate debate underlines the fact that the Government does not have a coherent and comprehensive policy for its Government business enterprises. It has what it describes euphemistically as a government business enterprise reform package, which is designed to apply more market pressure to business enterprises, to give them more flexibility and to take them out from underneath some of the more onerous responsibilities of being part of the bureaucracy. That is a step in the right direction, but it is a bit like entering a marathon when one has callipers. It is probably something one can do, and one should be given credit for trying, but the reality is that a lot more could be done, and done fairly quickly, without any major problems, except upsetting the factional balance within the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I hear a member of the left wing chuckling away. It is a pity that the honourable member was not here earlier because he might have been embarrassed about what I said, as it happens to be true that the left wing has been set up. The right wing could not quite get the numbers on the day to push this through, but let me tell my friend it will. The left wing has lots of principle but not much clout. Everything that it supposedly stands for will finally be run over by the right wing. I guess it will have its pursuit of totalitarian foreign policy or something to give it some comfort.
—In black Africa.

—In black Africa, at some stage. When it comes down to economic policy influence in this country the Left is just an obstruction to the inevitable change that will occur. This Government will not be making that change because it will not address it before the next election and it will not be here after the next election. If we are to get our economy moving properly, the Government has to get out of unnecessary business enterprises, particularly those enterprises that can be transferred to the private sector. The drain on the public purse has to be ended. We must have efficiency and competition. We cannot have selective competition. If our economy is to be open and if we are to operate on international standards, it has to be international right across the board. Let us not look after our mates and protect our friends; let us have some competition right across the board-a truly level playing field. Let us not build a little wall around one section of it because the unions in that section of the Australian Council of Trade Unions can be a bit difficult. Maybe that upsets the balance and could cost Simon Crean his job before he manages to get himself elected to this place. Maybe Halfpenny cannot become President too quickly if we upset that balance. The Australian taxpayer is not worried about that. What we and the taxpayers want is a government that gets away from policy paralysis, a government that addresses the problems and comes to grips with what it needs to do. The measure before us tackles only about one-tenth of the job. It is a great pity that the Government did not go further. Whilst we are critical of its failure to go the whole way, we will not oppose the Bills.
