—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's transport and communications enterprises have done well for Australia. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) mentioned what he saw as the need for attention to the Australian National Line and waterfront and shipping issues. I know that my friend and colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who has far greater expertise than either the honourable member for Richmond or me, will be able to deal with this matter properly at a later stage in the debate. What I do say to the honourable member for Richmond is that when the Government deals with the waterfront and shipping issues, it will be easily seen that the Government has the stomach to deal with them. The successes of other government enterprises relate to positive measures taken by Labor governments to strengthen government-owned transport and communication services as operating enterprises. The Whitlam and Hawke governments have strengthened the services rather than protected them. The Fraser Government was notable for the way in which it weakened enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two main objectives in the Government's approach to all the transport and communications issues: firstly, the need for increased efficiency and, secondly, the need for adequate services to both urban and rural areas. Admittedly, governments, both Labor and coalition, have always been prepared to ensure that our very productive rural and outer urban areas continue to receive reasonable services, sometimes cross-subsidised by inner city areas, but there is some doubt now about the Opposition's policy. For instance, the Liberal policy is quite unclear. One version says that it will sell the lucrative parts of government enterprises to private enterprise. Then what? Will the user pay more in the country? Will the user have to pay the full cost, perhaps doubling telephone rentals, so that costs are covered? Will we all pay higher taxes to subsidise those services, or will the services be reduced in number and quality? It will probably be the lot. The Nationals, including my friend the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), would well and truly know that all these alternatives-higher charges, higher taxes and reduced services-are unacceptable to Australian people, particularly country people.

The Liberals may never implement their policy. Will they return to their ad hoc policies of not liking government enterprises but having to put up with them because of the National Party? Would they lack the stomach, to quote the honourable member for Richmond? That would be just as dangerous. We would return to those Fraser years when government enterprises were discriminated against, yet no effort at all was made to increase their efficiency or profitability. Honourable members should look at what happened to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, which has now been turned into a profitable enterprise from an unprofitable one. It is now obtaining jobs overseas which were kept from it under the Fraser Government.

In short, coalition actions and coalition words lead us to a confusing range of possibilities, depending on whom one believes. Privatisation of the lot and letting the rural and urban Australian pay more, with the central business district paying less, is one proposal. Sell off the lucrative parts, with higher charges, higher taxes and reduced services, is another version. The whittling away of government enterprises by conscious channelling of business elsewhere was the indecisive action shown by Fraser. Even the Liberal leadership in opposition is showing strong evidence of indecisive action, being unable to come to decisions, just the same as it was when in government. It is unable to make decisions; unable to make the hard decisions. None of those choices are acceptable.

It is interesting that government enterprises have become more efficient because of the actions of reforming governments. In 1975 the Whitlam Labor Government took the bold step of creating from the Postmaster-General's Department two major public enterprises-Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Time has proved the correctness of that decision. Australia has a technically advanced and highly reliable telephone service. The telephone network has continued to expand and now well over 90 per cent of Australian households have a telephone service. However, the increasing importance of telecommunications to our economy necessitates further building on the achievements to date. Consequently, the Government has decided to continue the process of commercialisation by adopting a reform package which will put Telecom on a sounder commercial footing.

For example, under the Bill that is before us this evening, in future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of Telecom. Instead, it will focus on planning through corporate plans and financial targets and accountability for results, with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. In future the emphasis will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. That is a better way than the Thatcher way, which has brought high costs for installation of telephone services, lower wages in regional areas of the United Kingdom for Telecom workers and a lowering of service standards in the United Kingdom.

Next we have the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) is a relatively small but extremely efficient government enterprise. It will be able to pursue its role independently. I am pleased about that because OTC-this organisation which the honourable member for Richmond wants to sell-has an operating profit after tax that is up 16 per cent to a record $68m for the year ended 31 March 1987. It has a dividend for 1986-87 set at $40m-an increase of 33.4 per cent. Its combined tax and dividend paid to the Commonwealth Government totalled $96.68m-an increase of 34 per cent. Again, the honourable member for Richmond wants to deny these funds to the owners of the enterprise, the Australian people. These results were obtained despite adverse effects of foreign exchange movements which significantly impact upon OTC's operations. All this comes from international telephone services, leased services revenue and data services, although there was a decline in telex and telegrams, as would be a natural event in the trend of communications around the world.

We need to remember what the principal statutory functions and duties of OTC are when we are considering whether it should be government owned or privately owned. It is there to establish, maintain and operate public telecommunications services between Australia and other countries, ships at sea and the external territories and for services between the external territories. In other words, OTC is our link with the world. OTC is also a great revenue maker. It can tell many overseas firms how to get business. So, there are good cases in favour of full public ownership of OTC. The original objective of ensuring national ownership and ready government control of Australia's external telecommunications system still applies today. Government ownership helps ensure a secure network which, when required, gives priority to defence and national security interests.

OTC's record shows that it is able to operate efficiently as well as achieve significant profits. It stands up well in comparison with similar overseas organisations operating in the private sector. This suggests that OTC would continue to perform well under private or public ownership. So, why privatise OTC? In future under this legislation the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of OTC. Instead, it will focus on planning through corporate plans and financial targets and accountability for results, with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. A myriad of unnecessary government controls over day-to-day management decisions will be removed.

Another government enterprise I would like to look at is Australia Post-an organisation with a long and very distinguished history. It has given long and efficient service to Australia. I note that Australia Post charges about half the amount charged in West Germany to post a basic article in the mail. Once again, time has shown that the Whitlam Government was right to divide the then Postmaster-General's Department. In the 11 years before 1975 the postal operations of the Postmaster-General's Department consistently showed a loss. Since 1975 Australia Post has made a profit in every year but one. In future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day to day activities of Australia Post. Under the Postal Services Amendment Bill 1988, which we are considering this evening, it will focus on planning through corporate plans and financial targets and accountability for results, with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully goals and targets are met, just as with Telecom. The Government aims to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the board and management.

The Bill also includes amendments to allow Australia Post to develop its properties commercially. In many cities throughout Australia the post office is located in the heart of the town. These sites are prime real estate, but the existing constraints on Australia Post's powers have inhibited their commercial development. In line with Australia Post assuming responsibility for the telegram service, the Bill recognises that Australia Post's electronic mail services are equivalent to the traditional telegrams they will replace. Lettergrams, like telegrams, will be able to be ordered by telephone or across post office counters. Australia Post will undertake their delivery.

The Government members committee on transport and communications, which I am pleased to chair, is also doing some important work with Australia Post in trying to raise the number of non-postal services provided in post offices. This will have a dual effect of providing services which are not at present being provided, particularly in outer suburban and country areas, as well as tending to maintain the viability of post offices in small country areas and outer suburban areas. For instance, we are asking Australia Post and Federal departments to look at the provision of a range of government services. At present Australia Post is providing services in regard to passports and citizenship. It has been found that its services are being provided on a very competent basis. In fact, the error rate has not increased; in some aspects it has declined in the provision of those services. It is important that we build on those services. It is important that we make full use of the staff in Australia Post who are prepared to provide those services. We need to look perhaps at Telecom Australia providing some services from post offices, particularly the display and sales of different types of telecommunication services which it has available. We should look at the possibility of some government departments, such as the Commonwealth Employment Service, Social Security and Medicare, providing basic services by means of computer links from post offices.

Above all, no matter which services we are looking at we need to continue the objectives I mentioned at the beginning. We should remember the need for increased efficiency in government services and the need for the continued provision of services to rural and urban areas with the same zeal which has brought success to many government enterprises, including the Commonwealth Bank, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation. The Government should not blindly follow privatisation. I am pleased that in regard to this legislation it is recognising that. I think the Government should recognise that, because Australia has an unevenly distributed population, it needs to provide services to the rural sector, which produces half our exports, as well as to the urban sector. For that reason I am pleased to support all the legislation before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly strongly support the amendment moved by the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), because I think it reflects the very real and intelligent commitment on this side of the House to improving the performance of these government business enterprises-an issue about which already tonight I have had a little to say in this House. It was interesting to hear the previous speaker, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), reiterating the view we have now heard from so many people in the Australian Labor Party-not, of course, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or Senator Gareth Evans, but from so many others-that they still favour government ownership. Ideologically they still favour nationalisation. They still favour government control of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC). They still favour the nationalisation of Aussat Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank-which does not come under the purview of this package of legislation. So the list goes on. The fact is that although many people in the Labor Party, not least the Prime Minister and Senator Gareth Evans, know that the intellectual argument in favour of nationalisation, as I will choose to call it tonight, is lost, they still cling to their ideology and the memories of Chifley and their forebears like drowning men clinging to a life raft. The fact is that throughout the world, even in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, it has increasingly been recognised that government monopolies just do not work. The only exception is where there is simply no alternative to a government monopoly. In some of the activities of Australia Post and Telecom Australia that is obviously the case. Where there is no alternative, such government monopolies are acceptable. However, it has been shown again and again all around the world that government monopolies, where competition and enterprise are the alternatives, simply do not work.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to digress-I think this is highly relevant to the debate-but the fact is that one of the reasons the economies of east Europe, Central and South America and some of the less progressive Asian countries have been so unsuccessful is that they have pursued monopolistic policies in enterprise. The monopolies are sometimes owned by government, particularly of course in east Europe. Sometimes they are owned by special and privileged families, as in parts of Central America, South America and, of course, in countries such as, I hope, the pre-Aquino Philippines. The simple fact is that these monopolists have been extorting monopoly rents from the consumers in society-from the ordinary people of those countries-and have been pocketing those monopoly rents in different ways. In east Europe they have been pocketing the monopoly rents in the form of privileges and special salaries and so on for the bureaucracy and apparatchiks of the Communist Party. In Latin America a small number of people have been pocketing the monopoly rents, the monopoly profits, in the form of massive incomes while the rest of the community lives in total poverty. The ghastly contrast between prosperity and poverty, between massive wealth and dire poverty, in so many of those parts of the world is, once more, a reflection of the old policy of concentrating economic power in monopolies, in the hands of far too few people.

In this country we too have been extorting monopoly rents in some enterprises. In the Australian National Line, it is the Seamen's Union that has been extorting the monopoly rents because of practices such as overmanning on the ships. There are practices that we have seen in other areas of the waterfront. The list goes on. That is the way we have been distributing monopoly rents taken away from the productive sector of our economy. Therefore, when we talk about the privatisation of these enterprises we on this side of the House are talking about providing competition so that enterprise remains honest, so that enterprise ends up reducing its cost to the lowest level practicable and, at the same time, ensuring that the consumers are first and foremost. If we have a monopoly the result of that monopoly is simply going to be that the consumers come second and that the people who come first are the monopolists who control the monopolies. If ever there was a winning argument for privatisation, for private enterprise and competition, that is the argument that finally floors those people in the Labor Party who have successfully demolished politically the standing of the Prime MInister on the whole issue of privatisation.

Of course, the other issue which the Government itself has come to recognise is that as a result of being public enterprises these enterprises simply are unable to raise appropriate capital. As I am going to point out in a minute in relation to Australian National Railways, the growth in the long term debt to equity ratios of those sorts of enterprises is a very serious problem. Again, it is hampering the ability of those enterprises to be able to provide services and goods to the people who really count-the men and women of Australia, the consumers of this country. The Prime Minister recognises that. He has been rolled by his Party. Senator Evans, when he was the Minister for Transport and Communications, recognised that. He was rolled by his Party. Most people around the world now recognise that-even in Eastern Europe. However, the Labor Party remains ideologically and blindly committed to public enterprise for the sake of public enterprise because it can see no further than the dim distant memory of its friend Ben Chifley.

I think that if we make a selection from the package of Bills in the cognate debate tonight the example provided by the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill is as good a one as any. I know that the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has a keen interest in the Australian National Railways. I doubt very much whether he would demur from many of the conclusions I would draw from the operation of that enterprise. This Bill enables Australian National to operate more freely as a business enterprise. The Bill is not a major initiative; it is a minor technical initiative. However, it does enable Australian National to operate still more freely as a business enterprise.

I welcome the opportunities that Australian National Railways has had over the last decade or so to become more business oriented than it used to be. I happen to hold the old-fashioned view that railways still have a future in this country. We ought to be providing from this Parliament confidence for the railways and for the people who work in the railways, recognising that their contribution to our economy is respected and should be rewarded and, more than that, that over the next 20, 40 or 50 years railways may very well assume a greater level of importance than they have had in the last two or three decades in this country. I think that Australian National Railways is very much of that view and has been very determined to try to improve the efficiency of its operation ever since the Fraser Government made changes to Australian National Railways to allow it to do so. It has to be conceded that this Government in this legislation is building on the initiatives of the Fraser Government. It is a process that has been going on for some years.

I certainly pay tribute to Don Williams, the present Chairman and former General Manager of Australian National Railways, for all he did to make that railway much more successful. The Government has injected entrepreneurship into Australian National Railways in the area of passenger trains. It has introduced the entertainment car on the Ghan and, as everyone would know, has been putting forward a much more aggressive advertising posture. It has also been rationalising and improving its freight services very substantially.

The fact is that Australian National Railways still has many major problems. Those problems need to be addressed properly. First, Australian National Railways needs to be much better integrated with the State railways, in particular the Victorian railways and the New South Wales railways, if it is going to be a truly successful national railway system. It really is a major problem for Australian National Railways to try to promote one trans-Australian freight service when it has to go through marshalling yards at Parkes, Broken Hill, Port Augusta and Dry Creek-and so the list goes on-adding enormously to the delays in the service and to the costs of the service that otherwise it would be able to provide. I think the Commonwealth Government, in cooperation with the State governments, has to work very hard on trying to integrate more successfully the freight services of Australian National Railways with those of the various State railway systems.

Secondly, we have the age-old problem of standardisation of track in Australia. This is hardly new; it goes back well over a century. But the fact is that the costs associated with the variation of railway gauges throughout the country are also enormous. One only has to go, as has the honourable member for Throsby, to the Dry Creek marshalling yards to see the facility for changing bogies to appreciate that, although it is a very effective facility and is quite cost effective for what it does-it is technologically advanced even though, I am sorry to say, the technology is not Australian-the fact is that it is slow and therefore is going to be time-consuming and cost ineffective compared to not having to go through that bogie changing process. In the long term, if our railways are to succeed, there will have to be a major investment in the standardisation of track, not least between Adelaide and Melbourne, so that freight trains can link up directly with cities such as Sydney and with the eastern seaboard without having to go through, at the very best, bogie changes and, at the worst, changes of train altogether. I hope that I will live to see the day-indeed, I hope it will be a lot sooner than that-when there is some constructive proposal that can be funded, particularly if it can be funded with private sector finance, for the introduction of a standard gauge line between Adelaide and Melbourne.

The third problem of Australian National Railways-and this is a problem that has not been highlighted sufficiently-is that it has a drastic lack of capital. Again, I know that the honourable member for Throsby is only too well aware of the problems of the lack of capital that Australian National has. Let me give the House a couple of statistics: in 1977-78, the halcyon years of the Fraser Government, Commonwealth equity in Australian National Railways was 68.3 per cent of the total capital structure of Australian National Railways. In 1986-87-and these are the latest figures available-Commonwealth equity in Australian National Railways was 34.8 per cent of its capital structure. What is of concern is that the level of debt in Australian National Railways has grown enormously. It is the servicing of that debt which is using up so many of its resources, rather than being able to concentrate its financial resources on continuing to build an effective railway system. In 1977-78, 21.1 per cent of the capital structure of Australian National Railways was in Commonwealth loans. In 1986-87, it is 30.7 per cent. Other loans, which were zero in 1977-78, are now 12.2 per cent. So honourable members can see an enormous increase in the level of indebtedness of Australian National Railways and the decline of equity in that railway system.

One of my concerns about that is that Australian National Railways is being forced into more and more obscure financing arrangements which I do not think are necessarily going to be in the long term interest of that railways system, even though they provide for some short term advantages. Nobody has publicised the fact that Australian National Railways has purchased a series of new Clyde locomotives, which is a good thing. That aspect of it has been publicised. Nobody has publicised the fact that Australian National Railways has already sold most of the locomotives or is in the process of selling most of the new locomotives it has just bought to finance companies, be they Australian or foreign-and I understand some of those finance companies are foreign-and is leasing back those locomotives from foreign finance companies. It is entering into this sort of shonky Bannon-style lease back arrangement because it has no other source of capital to pay for the new locomotives.

I have a real concern about the way public enterprises in Australia-and, worse than that, State governments such as the State Government of South Australia, which has done it with its power stations-are entering into these curious lease back system which do not provide them with any particular tax advantages, as they might to a private sector company, but which do raise short term capital requirements for the public enterprises and incur a substantial long term liability. I wonder what the effective interest rate is on the locomotives that Australian National Railways is in the process of selling and leasing back. I wonder whether the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, will be able to give us the answer to that in his summing up speech this evening. We as a parliament need to know what is happening to the resources of this public enterprise which is answerable to the Parliament of Australia. If the Government is not prepared to tell us what is happening, if the Minister is going to follow the precedent set by his dear friend and colleague, the Premier of South Australia-I am only being facetious, Mr Deputy Speaker; I know they are not friends-who has told the State of South Australia nothing at all about the way he has flogged off and leased back the State's power stations and all the other shonky financial deals that the South Australian Government financing authorities are getting involved in, then doubtless the Parliament is simply going to be denied this information.

I have sympathy for Australian National Railways in this case, because it must try to raise more investment capital. It really has only two choices if it is not going to enter into these so-called creative financial deals. One choice is to come to the Government, cap in hand, and just ask for a cheque. That is the choice that the honourable member for Throsby supports. I am sure he thinks that the Government should write out a big fat cheque for Australian National Railways. If he does not think that, I assume therefore that he thinks it is a good thing that its debt to equity ratio is continuing to grow from 0.3 : 1 in 1977-78 to 1.2 : 1 in 1986-87. There has been a bit of growth there. If the honourable member for Throsby thinks that that is a good thing, so be it. If he does not, he probably favours a big fat cheque from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to try to solve that problem. We, on this side of the House, are not too keen on governments writing out big fat cheques. At the end of the day the solution will probably be something much more creative than that, involving some of the many private enterprise transport corporations in the activities of Australian National through investment processes. I think that is the way to go in the longer term. That will inevitably happen if Australian National, as a railway system, is to raise appropriate capital.

I really have some reservations about some of the alternatives, such as the third alternative plan; that is, the old lease back arrangement. It reminds me very much of the case in Britain when the Manchester City Council, trying to circumvent the conservative government's very appropriate spending controls on it, became so desperate for money that it actually sold the Manchester Town Hall and leased it back. From what I understand, it was about the only asset that the Manchester City Council had. The British Government has made that sort of practice illegal.

In this country our public enterprises are so desperate for capital that they are doing the same thing, because of the ideological opposition from the Labor Party to privatisation or private sector involvement. Indeed, our Labor State governments are also indulging in some of the same sorts of financial practices. I hope that the Government will be more sympathetic to the problems of Australian National Railways because the management of that company has improved enormously over the years. The present management is doing a professional and constructive job but we ought to be told the real story of the leasing back of the new locomotives whose purchase the Prime Minister announced only recently.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I will confine most of my remarks to the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. It is a major step towards implementing the reform package announced by Senator Evans on 25 May 1988 in his statement `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Enterprises'.

The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in his wide-ranging speech about what the Opposition would sell off and so forth, mentioned the steel industry plan. I do not know what the steel industry plan has to do with this. I see that my good friend the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) pricked up his ears when I said that. When this Government came to power in 1983 the steel industry in Australia had been devastated. Both the honourable member for Macarthur and I know that because we represent the steel producing area. This Government has rebuilt the steel industry. We now have a viable industry that is competing throughout the world. Had the Fraser Government been re-elected in 1983 Australia today would not have a steel industry. So enough of this nonsense about the steel industry plan.

A major part of the Government's third term agenda is micro-economic reform. Ensuring that government business enterprises operate as efficiently and effectively as possible is a major element of this reform program. ANL provides an important transport link for Australian industry, both internationally and on the coast. Any improvement in its efficiency will therefore be reflected immediately elsewhere in the economy. But this will occur only if ANL is given greater flexibility and the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to take up business opportunities as they present themselves. The staff of ANL, especially members of the sea-going unions, have played a significant part in this turnabout in ANL.

The honourable member for Richmond, in his usual manner, displayed his ignorance about the Australian shipping industry. It is not surprising that the Opposition should display this ignorance. In fact, I expect it. Honourable members opposite see the chance to do a bit of union bashing and away they go. As usual, they are not concerned with the facts; they are after blood-the blood of honest and decent Australian working men. When one strips away their biased rhetoric and their outdated so-called facts, one begins to see what their real contribution has been-so far absolutely nil in this debate and nil for the years that they occupied the treasury bench. This Government has a good record in Australian shipping. We can be proud of our record; it is in stark contrast to that of those now sitting opposite. When they were in government they did absolutely nothing to improve and modernise the Australian shipping industry.

I found it interesting that the honourable member for Richmond talked about this Government being confused. He spoke about factions in this Government. Honourable members opposite should talk about factions in a political party! As for being confused, it is obvious from his speech that the Opposition is confused about the maritime industry. Honourable members opposite spend most of their time talking about the waterfront unions. They obviously cannot tell a seaman from a wharfie, a wharfie from a painter and docker, or a painter and docker from a fireman or deckhand.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have never done an honest day's work in their lives.

—As my honourable colleague says, they have never done an honest day's work in their lives, most certainly not on the waterfront. They should come with me some time to Port Kembla. I know some seamen, waterside workers, painters and dockers, firemen and deckhands who are most eager to support--
—They are a good group.
—The honourable member for Adelaide will not interject and if wishes to address the Chair, he should occupy his own seat.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. These people are most eager to help Opposition members understand the differences. Of course, as the honourable member for Richmond told us the Opposition wants the Australian coastline opened up to foreign shipping. This would be an absolute disaster, not least in that it would add to our balance of payments deficit because the earnings of foreign shipping lines would be sent overseas and no tax would be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: I have on several occasions challenged members of the Opposition to come with me to Port Kembla to inspect one of the rust buckets that periodically enter our port. To date no-one has accepted my offer. I have been aboard a number of these rust buckets. The conditions for the crew are appalling but, worse than that, they are such that the safety of the ship and crew is seriously at risk. Of the 314 major maritime accidents recorded in 1984, all but a handful were due to defective vessels, faulty navigation equipment or inadequate safety training for the crew. Over the period that this Government has been in power, there has been an enormous improvement in industrial relations in the shipping industry, an improvement virtually unmatched in any other Australian industry. The recently released Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report does not even mention this very significant factor which has done so much to make Australian shipping more competitive. This raises the very serious question of the validity of the report. One cannot help but ask whether it is a balanced and fair report. The facts are that the Opposition is seriously out of date; in fact it is 10 years out of date as illustrated by the comments it makes on Australian shipping, and it keeps making these out of date comments all the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of touch.

—It is out of touch, as my honourable friend says, and out of date. The maritime unions have long since recognised the need to reduce crew levels on Australian shipping in order to make the industry more competitive and they have set up the necessary procedures to meet this challenge. Yet we hear the honourable member for Mayo, in his contribution, talking about overmanning on Australian ships. Has he not heard of the multiskilling that has occurred in recent years on Australian ships? There has been a reduction to 23 and 21 on these ships. Shipping unions then recognised the need to amalgamate so that they could eliminate the causes of demarcation disputes on board our ships and today the amalgamation process is almost complete. The unions also recognised the importance of multiskilled training for the members of ships' crews, so that the one crew member can effectively perform a number of functions previously carried out by two or more crew members belonging to different shipboard unions. To give crew members the necessary multiskilled background, there was set up in Launceston in 1975, some 13 years ago, a training school to do just this-rather than holding back progress by sticking to outmoded work practices. SPEECH.PARA: The maritime unions have sought to move with the times, and I must say they have done a pretty good job of it. A more appropriate comparison would be one between Australian seamen and other Australian workers.

After listening to the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Mayo-although he spoke mainly about the railways-one would have thought there had been no progress at all in Australian shipping. An Australian crew will replace a Japanese crew on a Japanese car-carrying ship early next year because it will be cheaper . . .

It will be cheaper to employ an Australian crew on this ship than it would to employ a Japanese crew. So much for the costs in Australia. It would do honourable members opposite good to talk to some of the seagoing unions, to get an up-to-date education and to accept the invitation that I constantly offer to them to come to Port Kembla with me and the honourable member for Macarthur to meet the workers of the Australian maritime industry, the seagoing unions and those who work on the wharves.
