SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the six cognate Bills before the House, and make particular reference to the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill. As has been mentioned by honourable members, this is important legislation which will widen Australian National's powers to expand the scope of its business activities, to extend the planning and accountability mechanisms which apply to it and to remove most of the remaining day to day controls over Australian National activities. It is to some extent all about the future of rail and providing the right corporate plan as specifically provided for in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As the House considers this legislation, it is food for thought to pause for one moment and think that 25 years ago we were on the brink of the major standardisation projects which brought about the big breakthrough at that time in rail transport infrastructure. I take this opportunity to quote from a speech by William Charles Wentworth, the then member for Mackellar, to the House on 2 May 1963:
I hope I will not be named as one of the people who have been luke-warm about this-
in effect, the subject of rail standardisation. He continued:

As honourable members know I had the honour to be the chairman of the committee which recommended the scheme of rail standardisation, of which this line is the final, or nearly the final, link. We have seen the scheme carried out step by step.

Also as part of the membership of that committee was a former member for Farrer, indeed the first member for Farrer, Sir David Fairbairn. These were giant men of considerable foresight who helped bring about the key standardisation breakthroughs of Albury to Melbourne, of Broken Hill to Port Pirie and through to Port Augusta, and eventually of Kalgoorlie to Perth, and paved the way, in effect, for more recent links including the vital link from Crystal Brook to Adelaide. But as progress has been made on the one hand, to some extent on the other hand we have stood still, because 20 years ago we had this-and I bring to the attention of the House the Main Southern Line and Branches timetable of Tuesday, 10 September 1968. The line passes through the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), and lists amongst other things such illustrious trains as the Intercapital Daylight Express, leaving Sydney at 7.45 a.m. on Mondays to Saturdays and arriving in Melbourne, having passed through Goulburn and Albury, at 8.20 p.m., some 12 1/2 hours later. I have to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House that precisely the same timetable operates on this day, 1 November 1988, for the Intercapital Daylight Express as operated on Tuesday, 10 September 1968-20 years ago. So as we take this opportunity to look at a window of change in respect of railway development in this country, I have to report to the House and the nation that while some progress has been made in one sense, in another sense very little progress has been made and we have some terrible anomalies.

Let me state my position very clearly. Last month I said at one of an important series of meetings convened by the Jerilderie Shire Council that rail has a very strong future in the twenty-first century. I was speaking about revamped and revitalised rail transport in Australia and, indeed, around the world. I might add that underlying that fundamental strength of rail transport is the basic energy equation and the shortage of oil by degrees, especially here in Australia. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) asked a question today about the severe rundown in our oil reserves that we are going to suffer throughout the next decade. More than ever we must take into account the simple equation that a steel wheel on a steel rail has approximately one-tenth of the friction of a rubber tyred wheel on a bitumen surface. It is that simple equation which demonstrates the efficiency and effectiveness of the rail infrastructure around the world.

This equation will be responsible for a massive leap forward in rail development with the completion of the twin railway chunnel between the United Kingdom and France. This standard gauge railway line will provide a quantum leap forward in the swing back to rail in Europe and the United Kingdom in respect of not only passengers but also freight. Even in the United States of America where the car has been god for so many decades, we now see Amtrak making some progress towards developing viable operations between Boston, New York and Washington, in what the Americans call their north-eastern corridor, and on some of its other route structures. Some of its operations are swinging heavily back into profit. Carefully managed and very long unit train loads of freight are competing very effectively.

Much needs to be done here in Australia. I acknowledge that the legislation that is before the House tonight takes a further step towards bringing about a more commercial orientation to our Australian National operations. I digress for one moment. I mentioned some very effective meetings that were called by the Jerilderie Council in relation to the railway line which runs from Narrandera to Jerilderie and Tocumwal and the question of standardising the Tocumwal-Mangalore link to allow for a second standard gauge link from the Riverina ultimately through to Geelong and certainly to Melbourne.

Over the years Jerilderie has been a very big railway centre and a very big consignor of excellent high quality stock. Years ago all of the stock and merchandise produced on Tom and Heather Pyle's property would have been sent by rail. But that rail link is no more. In fact, following the meetings, it was announced that the Jerilderie to Tocumwal section would be permanently closed. That being the case, we are losing the right to advance further the cause of standardisation between Narrandera, Mangalore and Melbourne.

I make the point in the context of this Australian National Railways legislation that we will live to regret the closure of the branch lines, regional lines and main lines by governments of all political persuasions and at all levels. While I am not about the business of featherbedding rail infrastructure to the extent of keeping branch lines running when such a proposition is clearly and completely beyond the pale, I do say that there is tremendous scope and potential for the revamping and revitalising of rail infrastructure in this country. Rail transport will enjoy a renaissance in the twenty-first century to an extent that economists, government planners and others ought to start thinking about here and now.

I am taking the opportunity, in the context of this debate and the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) which I have seconded, to make these points because it is rare that the House gets the opportunity to examine transport modes and to discuss rail transport in some detail. I hope that governments of all persuasions and at all levels, as they plan for the 1990s and beyond into the twenty-first century, will look long and hard at the use of modern effective railway systems to fulfil the need for both passenger and freight movements on the scale that they do so well. Clearly it would be uneconomic in the extreme to provide such a service to every small town in New South Wales or in the nation. But equally, this could be done well on such routes as Ballarat to Melbourne and on the electrified route from Brisbane to Rockhampton. The north coast so-called main line between Sydney, Newcastle, Taree, Grafton and Brisbane could be improved. This line needs to undergo some upgrading and revamping. Originally it was not much better than a rough branch line which followed every bend and went up every grade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking pressure off the highway.

—As the honourable member correctly points out, if it were turned into an effective, revamped, modernised main line, enormous pressure would be taken off an horrific section of the Pacific Highway along the north coast. At the same time more efficiency would be conferred overall on that transport corridor between Sydney and Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in that context that I turn to two other specific areas-firstly, the very fast train concept and, secondly, Australian National. I do so in the context of the corporate plan provided for in the legislation before the House. Firstly, I turn to the very fast train. Ten years ago Dr Paul Wild was thought to be a madman who had lost his focus and his mental balance because he had come forward with a concept of a three-hour train service between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne-Sydney to Canberra in one hour and Canberra to Melbourne in two hours. Today Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, TNT and a number of other companies and syndicates are forking out millions of dollars for very detailed feasibility studies of what is a planning reality and rapidly becoming an actual reality-namely, the very fast train travelling between Sydney, Goulburn, Canberra and Melbourne.

In recent weeks the Victorian State Government has decided to make a pronouncement on the very fast train concept after having held back for some time. The Victorian Government has said, `Yes, in principle, we support the concept. But, no, we are not quite happy yet about the basic route structure for the Canberra-Melbourne leg'. The State Government wants to place back on the agenda what I term the so-called western option-that is, a line running from Sydney to Canberra, Tumut, Holbrook, Albury and down the existing and very suitable corridor in terms of terrain to Melbourne. That line would be in contrast to the eastern option which thus far has been preferred by the very fast train syndicate and is subject to detailed investigation at the moment-namely Sydney, Canberra, Cooma, Gippsland and Melbourne.

The opening up of the western option question and the placing on the agenda of the route structure of the very fast train concept has great significance for Canberra. It has less significance for Goulburn because clearly the route will pass through Sydney, Goulburn and Canberra anyhow. But it has very great significance for the city of Albury, which I represent. It would boost existing rail infrastructure by providing direct access to the very fast train at various stages and especially at the key central hub point of Albury, quite apart from at Canberra and the Joppa Junction-Goulburn interchange, which is already on the planning boards at a site just south of Goulburn which the honourable member for Gilmore and I inspected about this time last year. One can see from the record of debates in State parliaments 100 years ago, from maps of my electorate and from looking out the window of a plane how so often the intervention of politicians has resulted in railway lines turning at right angles and heading off in all directions except where the line should be heading as people brought influence to bear on the planning of the lines for political rather than economic purposes.

I say that there should be a very detailed investigation of the western option: from Canberra, probably utilising the slightly easier grades around the Wee Jasper suboption, to Tumut, not necessarily involving costly tunnelling; from Tumut through Humula to Holbrook; from Holbrook through Table Top, past the Ettamogah Hotel, into Albury; and then resuming the existing standard and broad gauge railway corridor, on which there is quite sufficient space, from Albury to Melbourne. I suspect that that option has a lot to commend it commercially, economically and in every other way but for one thing-the difficult engineering link between Canberra and Tumut. Any decent Italian alpine engineer, road builder or rail builder would say that we should not get too fussed about that, given what the Italians have achieved in tunnelling and punching their way through mountains four times the size of the comparatively wimpish mountains between Canberra and Tumut.

These are fundamental questions, but at the end of the day the very fast train project must stand on its merits. It must stand on its economic viability and it must not be interfered with, even by the member representing Albury, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran)-dare I say it-or others. I call for and support a full investigation of the western option. Let it be compared with the eastern option through Gippsland but at the end of the day, whichever option stands up the best, we have to accept it and get on with the job. This country needs the very fast train. It needs it on its most important transport corridor-between Sydney and Melbourne-and it needs it by the year 2000, if not earlier. I back the project overall, and I commend Dr Paul Wild and the other people of great foresight who have carried the burden of this project, often against cynical criticism and indifference on the part of some front bench members of the Government, including the Minister referred to by the honourable member for Gilmore who at one stage attacked the project head on. He will live to regret that attack. I commend to the House the very fast train concept in the context of this legislation. It will impact on the corporate planning of Australian National. Let us get the best option. Let us find out what it is and then get on with the job.

I had the privilege in June of spending two days examining in some detail the workings of Australian National, along with my colleagues on a subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, including the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). It is interesting to see how Australian National has made great progress. It was not only under the Labor Government, of course; it was a coalition government that made some of the basic decisions about standardising the line from Alice Springs to Tarcoola and Port Augusta and so forth. But that is not what we are on about. We want to see Australian National get back into the black, ready for the twenty-first century. I am delighted to have seen at first hand its development of containerised wagons which allow for an articulated bogie construction with five long container wagons linked in such a way as to reduce the tonnage when empty by some 15 tonnes and confer a much greater economic benefit as a consequence. I have seen the way the organisation laser grinds its rails so that there is a one in 20 tilt to the rails on a horizontal examination and the efficiency that flows from that sort of progress. It is not just a steel wheel sitting on a steel rail; it is a wheel laser ground to a particular lateral profile sitting on a ground rail likewise dovetailed to provide maximum running efficiency. When we are looking at two-kilometre long freight trains, this is extremely important.

The big regret is that in the east-west operation we have the horrific situation of a freight train leaving Sydney having to have crew changes or be remarshalled at each of the following stations: Lithgow, Bathurst, Parkes-if it is lucky it might get through Orange without a change-Ivanhoe, Broken Hill, Peterborough, Port Augusta, Tarcoola, Forrest, Kalgoorlie, Merredin and Northam. Ultimately, eight days later, those wagons might happen to arrive in Perth. That trip takes place on one standard gauge. This is not good enough. That is why we have to look at the option of switching the Parkes-Broken Hill line to direct Australian National control and ownership. I call for that so that two-kilometre unit freight trains can operate directly from Parkes to Perth without remarshalling and without the massive featherbedding and delays caused by the present arrangements. The railways are moving in that direction. I welcome the trial run of a two-kilometre freight train from Parkes last week. I hope that further progress will be made. I commend the legislation to the House. More particularly, I commend the amendment so capably moved by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I will direct my remarks to the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988. This legislation will establish the Australian National Line (ANL) as a company by providing for the Australian Shipping Commission to be registered as a company incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory under the Companies Act 1981 on a date to be proclaimed. The company will be known as ANL Ltd. It is expected that the commencing date of the company's operations will be 1 July 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also removes certain statutory controls on the operations of the company. The Hawke Government has long been committed to a more competitive and efficient Australian National Line, capable of growth and greater job opportunities. The Australian National Line must be efficient to perform its important role as a transport link for Australian industry both internationally and on the coast. The Hawke Government has always believed that the Australian National Line had to be given greater flexibility and the ability to respond quickly to changes in the market and to seize business opportunities for expansion as they occur. In other words, the Australian National Line had to have the flexibility, the drive and the incentive to pursue opportunities and be a first-class commercial enterprise.

The initiatives of the Hawke Government to transform the Australian National Line from a debt-ridden loss maker into a profitable enterprise have been outstandingly successful. The transformation was difficult and hard won. Indeed, the history of the Australian National Line has been one of triumph over adversity and, under the Fraser Government, triumph over incompetent management when the line lost $40m. The Australian National Line was almost bankrupt at the time the Fraser Government lost office.

To enable honourable members to appreciate the need for this legislation, I will outline briefly the history of the Australian National Line. The line was established after the Second World War when the Commonwealth found itself in possession of a flotilla of merchant ships. In the early postwar period these ships continued to be operated by the Australian Shipping Board under the National Security (Shipping Coordination) Regulations. At the same time, the parlous financial state of the private shipping companies made it very difficult for them either to purchase the government ships or to have new ships built. In order to maintain Australian shipping services and to avoid the losses involved in disposing of its ships, the Menzies Government decided in 1956 to establish the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission, trading as the Australian National Line, and to operate its ships as profitably as possible. The private companies, for their part, were able to continue operations, mainly by chartering the vessels they required.

Originally established as a coastal shipping operation, the Australian National Line expanded its activities into international shipping services in the late 1960s and early 1970s. In recognition of this change in its role, the Commission changed its name to the Australian Shipping Commission in 1974. The financial performance of the Australian National Line throughout the 1960s and 1970s was patchy. In 1983 the Australian National Line was in a parlous financial position. Its debt-equity ratio was very high and it was on the brink of bankruptcy. The Hawke Government made a capital injection of $90m in May 1983. By using this to convert debt to equity, the Australian National Line was able to significantly improve its liquidity. As a quid pro quo, the Australian National Line agreed to improve its efficiency. A further injection of $70.541m was made by the Hawke Government in 1985. This was needed to place the Australian National Line's capital needs on an appropriate basis when this need became apparent following the adoption of more appropriate accounting practices by the enterprise.

The Australian National Line has engaged in a process of improving efficiency by reducing its fleet by around one-third and cutting back employment by a similar amount-almost 1,000 employees-over the period of 1983 to 1987. It has formulated a corporate plan and is attempting to implement lower ship manning levels. It has also ceased providing operations on a number of less profitable routes both on the coast and internationally. Indeed, one casualty was the ANL services from north Queensland. In 1983-84, the north Queensland service lost more than $6m and the ANL ceased its services to north Queensland, which produced much public opposition. The Australian National Line, in its 1986-87 annual report, argued:

. . . there is a limit to what can be achieved by corporate economies and internal efficiencies and further corrective action is inhibited now by the institutional rigidities in Australia of the industry itself and the competitive environment within which it is carried on.

The Australian National Line lists manning problems, industrial relations and problems on the waterfront as matters needing to be overcome for the enterprise to be able to continue in business and be profitable. This point of view raises several aspects. Firstly, it indicates that the prime concern is no longer one of the corporate structure of the Australian National Line. Secondly, it draws attention to the need for the Government's waterfront strategy to be fully and successfully carried out.

I now turn to a more detailed discussion of the need for this legislation. The blueprint for the commercialisation of several of the Commonwealth's more important business enterprises is set out in a document entitled Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises. This document was released by the Treasurer in conjunction with his May 1988 economic statement. That document draws attention to certain rigidities and non-commercial practices to be found in the operations of several business enterprises and argues that, for efficiency reasons, such problems need to be rectified. Indeed, the impetus for this legislation has been spurred by this document.

There have been many problems faced by government business enterprises. There has often been quite a deal of government intervention in the day to day operations of such enterprises. This has extended to staffing conditions, types and magnitudes of contracts that may be entered into, the type of securities which such enterprises could issue or invest in, and so forth. Enterprises have also been subject to more substantial intervention, such as having to meet superannuation liabilities under Public Service superannuation schemes, being subject to executive salary setting by the Remuneration Tribunal, and having to have borrowing programs approved by Loan Council. Frequently, enterprises have been allowed to continue with antiquated and inappropriate accounting practices. Such enterprises have also frequently been at the mercy of the Government's current budgetary `strategy' in terms of their access to appropriate levels of equity capital. Of course, not everything has been negative: several enterprises have operated for years either fully or partially exempt from the payment of Commonwealth, State or local taxation.

No one could seriously object to any government taking measures to correct these types of distortions. Indeed, the extent to which such distortions can be overcome solely by converting business enterprises into public companies, which is what this Bill is all about, is by no means clear. Although there could be certain advantages in incorporation, these are likely to be slight. The significant advantage would appear to be that, once an enterprise is a company, it is possible to sell off or issue shares in that enterprise. This may, of course, be advantageous to the enterprise in that it represents one way in which an enterprise can have access to capital, free from government budgetary considerations.

Certainly, it might be argued that, to date, whether an enterprise is a company or a statutory authority has had little impact on the degree of government intervention. Qantas, for example, is a company while Australian Airlines was, until recently, a statutory authority. Both were subject to fairly close government intervention in their operations, both were-and are-subject to Loan Council approval for their borrowings, and so forth. Despite their different corporate structures, there was effectively little difference in their relationship to government. One wonders about the fate of this particular Bill and its structure so far as ANL Ltd is concerned.

Over recent years, the Hawke Government has introduced legislation to free many authorities from day to day government controls. The Government has amended legislation establishing these authorities to grant whatever freedoms have been seen as appropriate. This has been done, and continues to be done, with enterprises such as the Australian National Line in this particular Bill, Telecom Australia, Australian National Railways and Australian Airlines. In the case of Qantas, an analogous procedure has been followed in that more liberal management directives have been provided to the organisation by this Government.

I just want to touch on a few more issues in connection with this debate, particularly with reference to the Bill. I turn to part V of the Bill, which deals with staff matters. I want to say a few words on remuneration. In recent years the legislation governing the activities of several statutory authorities has been amended to enable those enterprises to have more autonomy in setting the terms and conditions of employment of their staff. However, in most instances the salary of the general manager of the enterprise was set by the Remuneration Tribunal. This not only made it difficult to attract highly skilled people into the general manager's position but also put an effective cap on the salaries that could be offered to other staff. Often, more expensive consultants had to be engaged because the salaries needed to employ permanent officers could not be fitted into the enterprise's salary structure. This problem has been overcome by the introduction and probable passage-we hope-of the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill 1988. Part V of that Bill allows the Remuneration Tribunal to act in an advisory role only, allowing a business enterprise to set the conditions of employment of its managing director.

In relation to this Bill, I might mention also the capacity of ANL to borrow money. At present, borrowing by all government owned and controlled enterprises is subject to Loan Council control. In fact, Loan Council controls were strengthened in 1985 when the global borrowing limit program was announced. Such controls have applied not only to statutory authorities such as Australian Airlines, but also to public companies such as Qantas. It might be argued that, where government enterprises are commercial enterprises, especially where they are competing in the marketplace with private sector enterprises, the placing of artificial constraints on their borrowing is distorting as far as resource allocation is concerned, and is commercially disadvantageous to the enterprise. There have been many calls-justifiably so, in my opinion-for such artificial constraints to be removed. The Treasurer, in his blueprint, states that he will look into the possible exemption of Qantas, Australian Airlines and the Australian National Line from Loan Council control. Again, this could be done whether or not those enterprises were public companies.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will remember that as early as 1981 the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommended that, where it could be clearly demonstrated that a public authority was basically subject to market disciplines, it could be viewed as a commercial authority and, accordingly, the volume of borrowing by commercial local and semi-government authorities, and the terms and conditions of such borrowing, should be free from Loan Council control. Professor Campbell envisaged that this principle could be applied to any commercial authority, not solely to publicly owned companies.

One may very well ask: What are the benefits of incorporation as envisaged by the legislation? It is obvious that a major benefit of incorporation is that shares in an enterprise can be easily sold off, either fully or in part. Conversely, if an enterprise required capital but the Government felt that within the current Budget context such funding could not be provided within the public coffers, a new share issue could be made. This would dilute the Government's holding of that enterprise and that may be an act which may be inimical to the interests of ANL Ltd.

ANL Ltd, as it will be, we hope, after 1 July 1989, has a part to play not only as a commercial, viable shipping line that will benefit all ANL customers and the Australian economy but also in the defence and support of the country. Just as Australia needs physical defence by its Army, Navy and Air Force, so it needs instrumentalities such as the Australian National Line to prevent it from economic attack, which is one of the essential qualities that I see in ANL Ltd: it will be able to help prevent Australia from economic attack. This legislation is a step in the right direction in the pursuit of that goal. It is a reflection of this Government's commitment to a more competitive and efficient Australian national line and it is an endorsement, once again, of the goals set out in the Governor-General's Address when this Government was first elected in 1983 of national reconstruction, nation reconciliation and national recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a certain degree all the Bills that are being debated cognately lead to a form of privatisation of public utilities. I am pleased to see the legislation although, naturally, one can criticise it. I do not agree that the legislation goes anywhere near far enough in terms of the future of the organisations referred to. I spoke to the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill when it came before the House and I could reiterate some of the principles that I outlined at that time. Only months ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) reported to Australia that the Government wanted to proceed with the privatisation of a number of public utilities. I think that those comments were welcomed very favourably by the majority of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to appreciate that in this world of ours, particularly in Australia, we must be competitive with other countries. I can easily understand that in earlier days it was necessary for both Commonwealth and State governments, irrespective of their political persuasion, to move towards the provision of transport and communication services to meet the needs of a growing Australia. We should be very proud of what has been achieved to date with our railways, airways, shipping and telecommunications. In this bicentennial year we must appreciate that, recognising our place in this modern world, we have to be tremendously efficient in all of the utilities to which the legislation before us refers.

The Western world has found it necessary to privatise public utilities, simply because over the years the taxpayer has been unable to meet the growing demand on the public purse. This demand is growing for a number of reasons. I have already spoken about competitiveness and economic need. However, it has also been proven that in most cases a public enterprise is not as efficient as one that is privately operated. It is realistic to accept that. It does not apply in all cases and I must say that I am proud of what we are doing in the area of telecommunications and what Australia Post is doing. I am very proud of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. But we have to look into the future and be aware of what Australia requires.

Great advancement has been made in Britain and Europe. The privatisation of the steel and coal industries in Britain was strongly opposed by the unions. I was there in March and April and I believe that the miners are happy now. They receive much more pay than they received before and their conditions are better. They are satisfied with what has occurred there. We in Australia must recognise what has happened elsewhere and take it as an example. Undoubtedly, when the Prime Minister and the Treasurer first raised the matter of privatisation of these public utilities they did so because they had been overseas and had witnessed what had occurred. They said, `Righto, if it has happened there it has to happen in Australia. It is for the good of this country of ours that this takes place'. That is the reason the statement was made. As I said earlier, that is why we see the Government going part of the way in forming corporations dealing with transport and telecommunications.

I was very impressed with what the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said this evening. I believe that there is a place in this continent for an efficient railway system. It is a great shame that many of our spur lines and major services have been reduced considerably. They are in a rundown condition. I will not criticise the efficiency of management over the years. However, when one looks at a railway line, owned by the Commonwealth, running from Sydney to Perth and from Adelaide to Alice Springs, one thinks of the tremendous potential that such a line has in catering for tourism and the Australian domestic population. Such a line is, and will be in years to come, a great asset for Australians. We have so much to offer in the hinterlands of Australia, in Alice Springs and in areas on the way. We hope to see the line go to Darwin before very long. We would love to see another line from east to west across the north of Australia catering for the very significant natural resources in that area. We must be practical in the way we look at this.

As the honourable member for Farrer said, a railway line takes only a train on it. It does not take a motor car unless it is on a carriage. It does not have competition, and that is important. Today both the Commonwealth and the States are inclined to take competition away from the railways and the extra traffic goes on the highways-the main arterial and national roads of Australia. As the honourable member for Farrer said, we must be aware of this in terms of our future energy problems. Australia has these energy problems now. We are going to have them, along with the rest of the world. Basically, we have the natural resources that will drive our trains. We may even go back to steam. We do not know what the future holds. We may use nuclear power for the railways. The fact is that it is a fast and efficient way for people who want to travel on land.

People who want to travel in the air and who can afford to do so will do so. Rail travel is a form of transport for goods and passengers that we in Australia cannot afford to ignore. I hope that the legislation before the House will further assist this. I do not know how we should look at Australian National Railways or whether we should privatise it. It is a public utility. It is still in its infancy as far as its being built up is concerned. I would love to see the Government, no matter who was on the Commonwealth treasury bench, going ahead by building up and making those lines more efficient. The opportunity is there.

For years we have heard about the Australian National Line (ANL), that it is an inefficient line, that it is not properly run and that it is costing the Australian taxpayer a lot of money. I think that is true. Progress has been made. The present administration has made a certain amount of progress. ANL is now a paying line. I understand that it is responsible for only about 6 per cent of the international trade into and out of Australia. That is not very much. It is certainly more responsible for interstate trade. It hurts us when occasionally we read in the media that we can make a shipment from Cairns to Japan, Townsville to Japan or Melbourne to Japan more cheaply than a little trip around the coast on an ANL boat. We have to appreciate that there is something wrong with the management of the Australian National Line.

I welcome the legislation and hope that it becomes the means of creating a more efficient service so far as that line is concerned. If we attempted to privatise it, it might be quite a job because I do not know who would want to buy it. This is the important thing. We are competing against other very efficient shipping lines. It may not be opportune to say to the Australian people, `Will you buy shares in ANL?', because it would not be able to show the return to allow for that. I understand that a lot of our ships will soon need replacing. A lot of facilities onshore will have to be upgraded. We will have to have a better relationship between road transport generally and the shipping industry so as to be able to coordinate them, to keep our costs down and to make things much more efficient than they are at present. That is all I wish to say about ANL and Australian National Railways.

Telecom Australia and Australia Post are two organisations that virtually do not have any opposition. They are monopolies. It is easy for them to pay. We want to see them pay. We want to see them be commercial enterprises. Over the last 10 to 20 years we have gradually arrived at the point where they pay their way. It is quite easy for them because they are able to put up the price of their stamps and telephone calls at will. They are able to say that they will have to raise costs. They are able to raise the costs simply because they do not believe that they have any great competition.

Monopolistic as those organisations are, it has been pleasing to see that public relations within those two organisations have improved on what they were years ago. I only have to look at my own region within the electorate of Lyne to see how Australia Post has operated. Men such as Mr Maurie Thies, the manager in the Newcastle district, have given tremendous cooperation. I believe that we are getting the same cooperation from people within Telecom. We want to see that. When we go to the post office to post a letter, buy stamps or send telegrams it is nice to be met by a friendly face. This is demanded today by the Australian public. A different attitude exists from that which existed years ago. For instance, when people went on to a railway platform and someone growled at them they felt that they were in the road, but things have changed over the years. We do not want to queue for services, but I notice in post offices at home-it is the same in banks-and overseas that one has to queue before getting to the counter. I suppose it is something that we have to accept in Australia.

As I represent a country electorate I would like to say that the Government cannot lose control of the essential principles so far as Telecom and Australia Post are concerned. In other words, there must be some form of assistance from those paying enterprises to those which are not paying so well but are giving a service. This is essential. Within my electorate of Lyne six public telephones were taken out recently. I know that they were not paying telephones. The local people objected to this. The fact is that Telecom is a public utility. Whilst Telecom is showing those profits it has to carry the losses as well to provide a service to country people, particularly those in the outback who are many miles from the major towns and cities. Those people are serving Australia from a productive point of view on the land in primary industry and in mining the natural resources of Australia. They are the people who have to receive the services that are so essential for them to be able to carry on. There must be some government oversight of this. Whilst these are commercial enterprises that we are talking about, they certainly have to see that their services are provided for people who really matter.

Basically, that is my contribution on the legislation before the House. I am sorry that as far as Telecom and Australia Post are concerned there is not more contract work let out to give efficiency. I notice that the legislation makes it quite clear that all the staff which presently exist will be employed. I assume that if we were in charge of this legislation we might say the same thing. If it is going to be efficient, with the modern technology that we have, it is necessary wherever possible, for efficiency's sake, to keep staff numbers down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of these Bills. This is a cognate debate in which quite a number of Bills are being discussed. In particular, I want to concentrate on the communications area. We have had a number of changes of shadow Minister. I understand that the new shadow Minister for communications is Senator Lewis, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Having its shadow Minister in the other place probably reflects how contemptuously the Opposition treats the whole area of communications. I thought I should look at what Senator Lewis has contributed by way of policy in this area. He has made two speeches in the Senate that mentioned the word `Telecom', but they were in relation to broadcasts and the provision of antennae. So, it is no good looking at the speeches of Senator Lewis to get some clue about what the Opposition's policy is in relation to communications.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also looked at speeches made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) to see what he has had to say about Telecom and what the Opposition's policy might be. That was just a trifle more productive but really did not give me any clue. However, I thought in view of the fact that the honourable member for Richmond and the National Party of Australia had made some contribution to the debate today and made supporting statements about the need to ensure that there is cross-subsidy to rural and provincial Australia which, incidentally, I happen to support very strongly, I should read a little article from page 10 of the Daily Telegraph which is actually a rating of the Greiner Government.

Of course, we all know that the Greiner Government has broken quite a number of promises that were made prior to the election. I ask honourable members just to listen to this comment about the Leader of the National Party in New South Wales:
ASSESSMENT: Important in keeping the National Party loyal while rural areas bear so much of the brunt of Greiner's economic rationalism.

Of course, that is exactly what we have heard today. The leading ideologue in communications is not the shadow Minister or his representative in this House; it is my good friend Senator Richard Alston. Senator Alston makes no bones about the fact that he believes in a knee-jerk reaction to privatisation in the area of government business enterprises (GBEs). In fact, I think that any Australian listening to the contribution of the Opposition in this debate to date, in this bicentennial year, will have been struck in the way I have been struck by the fact that they are really so many colonists; anything that Mrs Thatcher has done in England ought to be replicated in Australia. Let us not have any originality of thought. Let us not tailor policies to suit the uniqueness of the Australian context and people but blindly follow the creed according to Thatcher.

These are the worst type of intellectual colonists that one could hope to see. All this is happening in our bicentennial year. I want to refer to a comment made by Senator Alston in the other place. He said:
The Government finds itself in a quandary over this issue.
He was talking about the changes the Opposition wanted to make to Telecom Australia in regard to privatisation. He continued:

This could be no better exemplified than by the recent decision of the Caucus to establish a loaded and one-sided committee of three to preserve and protect Telecom Australia. That Telecom preservation society has on it two former Telecom employees, and one other who presumably very much believes in protecting Telecom from any semblance of competition.

I am very flattered, I must say, to go down on the record as one of those people named as a protector of Telecom. I am certainly interested in protecting Telecom, its employees and its customers and in protecting Australian industry. If anyone from manufacturing industry is listening to this debate I ask him to have no doubt what Senator Alston would force on his party. Let him have no doubt what the Liberal Party of Australia would force through. It would completely wipe out Australian industry as we know it today. But, as I say, I am sure that my other two colleagues would be pleased to go into the record, as I am doing here, as protectors in this area.

Let me just pick up the issue of the protection of consumers. One of the most radical and real reforms brought about as a result of the May economic statement, and partially as a result of this legislation, is the establishment of Austel. Originally Austel was thought of as an independent regulator. One of the things the Government is committed to is ensuring that Austel will have a strong consumer function. It will ensure that system failures by Telecom are addressed by Telecom. In other words, we will no longer have the ridiculous situation that we currently have whereby the Commonwealth Ombudsman gets a host of individual complaints and certainly, as he has said, performs or conforms to the international standard of performance of ombudsmen by solving X per cent of cases. We do not get down to addressing the problems of the real management practices or systems failures that need to be addressed. Therefore, this Government legislation proposes to establish a strong consumer watchdog, Austel. It is no secret that we wanted to divorce the Ombudsman from this function and make Austel a one-stop shop. However, I am pleased to say that the Minister has agreed to review both the Ombudsman's handling of Telecom complaints as well as the way Austel is handling the system failures. This is a very real reform. For all those people who may feel superficially that privatisation is attractive, let me say that I have not heard one Opposition speaker or spokesman say that he supports a strong consumer body of the sort that we will be establishing with Austel from 1 July 1989.

I want now to get to the essential, I suppose, hypocrisy-I am sorry to use such a strong word-of the National Party of Australia. As I said, I happen to believe very strongly that rural and provincial Australia should not be disadvantaged. The National Party spokesmen will get up and say that Telecom is doing a good job or that Australia Post is doing a good job. However, when the crunch comes they will not be able to withstand the economic dries. They will not be able to prevent the abolition of the cross-subsidies should the Opposition ever get into government.

I would like also to deal with one proposition floated during the review. I refer to the proposal that we should make the cross-subsidy transparent and somehow put it on budget. Let us say, for argument's sake, that the cross-subsidy is $500m and that that is an on-budget item. The real danger with this purist approach, and I must say it has some attractions, is that it would be a very easy target for any Treasurer or Finance Minister wanting to rake in a few extra millions of dollars to reduce that amount of subsidy by X dollars-let us say that it was reduced by $50m or $100m, whatever we like-and then to say to that organisation that it will perform to the same standard. As I have said, I strongly support the Government in its determination to ensure a fair and equitable deal to rural and provincial Australia. I have some sympathy for National Party members when they get up and mouth those same words. However, as the Daily Telegraph showed today, in this new dry era of conservative politics, the National Party will not be able to stand up, as it has failed to do in so many areas in New South Wales, and get rural Australia to accept the full frontal force of the economic change that has been brought about. In this regard I could talk about the number of train services that have been cut and the number of charges that have been so outrageously increased. I warn rural and provincial Australia not to listen to the sweet talk coming from some sections of the Opposition but to listen to the ideologues in the Opposition, such as Senator Alston, who are really setting the agenda.

I should also have mentioned in regard to Austel that in fact one of its functions will be the setting of prices. The consumers of the goods and services provided by Telecom Australia will be paying for their services at a reduced rate. In other words, Austel, in setting the prices for Telecom goods and services, will be ensuring that a basket of goods will be provided at a cost less than the consumer price index and less than the real rate of inflation. Therefore, this Government in introducing these reforms has honoured a very strong commitment to the consumer. The consumer will be getting a far better deal through the changes that we have announced in the May economic statement. This legislation is but the first part of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak again on a topic that is very close to me; that is, the repatriation hospitals. During the last session of the House, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), with particularly sarcastic vitriol, attacked the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, my colleague the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), on the coalition's policy and attacked me for bringing on the repatriation hospitals debate. She had the juvenile temerity to sneer at `this much vaunted public meeting'. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not sermonise and mouth pious platitudes about veterans, we actually take action to ensure their welfare.
I add the now famous quote of the honourable member for Hawker that echoes around Australia: `Why should pensioners get special treatment?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? Repeat that.

—She said, `Why should pensioners get special treatment?'. Let me tell honourable members about the standing room only meeting for more than 200 pensioners and veterans at the Gilles Plains-Hampstead Gardens Returned Services League Club last Sunday morning-organised, I might add, at very short notice. I thank John Barrett, Bluey Roberts and their members, and the totally and permanently incapacitated and RSL executives who attended, along with the war widows and diggers. The honourable member for Hawker, true to her quote `Why should pensioners get special treatment?', is conspicuous by her inaction when it comes to helping pensioners and veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the August Budget there have been 70 Liberal, National and Labor politicians who have submitted over 5,000 petitions requesting that the decision to place over 50 pharmaceuticals on the authority-only listing be abandoned. These drugs are predominantly used by pensioners and veterans. Through our efforts on the Opposition and Government benches, and even with some help from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as well as other Labor members, 43 of those drugs have been brought back for review. But where was the great white hope from Hawker, demographically the oldest electorate in the nation? She is on the record as not going to give pensioners special treatment. Not one single petition was lodged from her office. There have been hundreds of petitions lodged in respect of the legislation seeking to reduce pension entitlements. But where is the honourable member for Hawker? It is too hard; she does not care. There has been not one petition on any issue. If honourable members do not believe me, they can go to the Bills and Papers Office and ask for the Votes and Proceedings.

Since 25 August, in the Budget session, dozens of members have lodged petitions containing thousands of signatures from elderly Australians, but not one has been submitted by the honourable member for Hawker. Then, in a bid to implement some damage control, we had a flurry of paper, with a press release in last week's Advertiser and letters to the editor congratulating the honourable member for Hawker on her stand for grey power. What an absolutely hypocritical beat-up!

Let us get to the heart of the matter; let us look at the facts: there have been 250 separate issues concerning a range of topics including veterans, pensioners, drugs, food irradiation, the greenhouse effect, the national flag-and the list goes on. Labor has presented petitions from 137 members from across the nation. The coalition is responsible for petitions being lodged in the names of 300 members, but not one issue has been of sufficient importance for the honourable member for Hawker to be bothered to collect some signatures. This is the woman who says that she actually takes action to ensure the welfare of these people-her words, not mine. I think that she must be confused.

Mr Acting Speaker, this is action: in my hand I hold more than 250 signatures relating to two specific grievances affecting elderly Australians. Of those, 71 signatures are from constituents of the honourable member for Hawker, the self-described woman of action. I am collecting petitions from her disgruntled constituents and they will be presented to the Table Office ready for Thursday. Perhaps the pensioners will benefit in the near future, after the Prime Minister opens the new Hawker electorate office on Friday, the second such office in 18 months. And what has this procession of offices cost the taxpayer, the veteran and the pensioner? Just a lazy $150,000.

He knows that, yet he comes in here and tries to make capital out of what drugs are on or off the available list. Having been sidetracked from what I wanted to say, I want to talk tonight about the contribution made to society by officers of agricultural departments in all States-with particular reference to Western Australia. Kalgoorlie, or the goldfields area, is soon to lose the services of Donald Burnside, who is going to Queensland to complete his Masters degree. Donald Burnside is an expert in arid land management and has worked in the rains and land management section of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture for some considerable time. He is very highly regarded in the goldfields for his dedication and the time that he puts in there. I know, because I have had occasion to ring him for advice on weekends only to find that he is out on some station or other.

From my experience, the overwhelming majority of stations in my electorate-and my electorate covers virtually all the stations in Western Australia-are in better condition today than they were 10 years ago. This is a tribute to the foresight of the people who now comprise the pastoral industry and to the work of the rains and land management section of the Department of Agriculture. It is a matter of some disquiet to me that, although this evidence is abundantly available, the Wilderness Society and the conservationists do not give enough credit to what has been done. In particular, I am concerned-and I am going to run out of time on this-at the hypocrisy these people show in respect of the kangaroo cull. Without maintaining the kangaroo cull it will be impossible to maintain regeneration. It will certainly slow the progress of regeneration and regeneration of this land is one of the most important problems facing the whole of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —World Expo 88 closed its gates in Brisbane for the last time on Sunday night after the most successful and most remarkable function of the Australian bicentenary celebrations. I think that it is only fitting in this House tonight that we pay tribute to the many thousands of people who contributed to the incredible success that World Expo 88 has been.

SPEECH.PARA: May I start by praising those members of the early Australian Bicentennial Committee who went to the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, and suggested that Australia should stage a World Expo during its bicentenary year. I pay tribute to the Fraser Government for having the foresight to go ahead with that recommendation. I pay special tribute to the then Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and indeed two Liberal Treasurers of Queensland-Sir William Knox and Sir Llewellyn Edwards-who were prepared to take up the challenge when the other States of Australia showed no interest at all in the World Exposition. We should pay tribute also to all members of the World Expo Authority staff, who worked under very trying conditions for some four years to make sure that Expo got off the ground.

In terms of direct contribution to World Expo, we should pay tribute to more than 10,000 volunteers who gave their time freely to work at Expo in a number of capacities and who, through their efforts, their friendship, their warmth and their professionalism certainly put Brisbane, Queensland and Australia well and truly on the world map. We should also pay tribute to more than 18 million people who went through the gates of World Expo. It is true that we have had in our community over the years a great number of knockers who said that World Expo would never work. There was one man whose vision, enterprise and dedication were such that he managed to prove all those knockers wrong. I pay a special tribute to the Chairman of the World Expo Authority, Sir Llewellyn Edwards, for staying with the job and for giving a great deal of service, personal commitment and leadership to make sure that World Expo 88 was one of the most successful expos in the world's history.

It is true that there were knockers at all levels of government. There were knockers in the Federal Government. I will not go back over that but I just want to acknowledge that not everybody in this place was happy with Australia going ahead with World Expo. There were certainly knockers in the Queensland Government. Many people in the Queensland community said that it would be a flop and that it would never get off the ground. There were also knockers in the Brisbane City Council who said that it could not be done. Sir Llew Edwards was a person who, despite the knockers, had the physical courage to go on with the job and make sure he saw it through. He made sure that he saw it become the incredible success that it was.

There is one person in this House that I would like to pay special tribute to tonight; that is, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). At a time when the Federal Government was really not terribly interested in World Expo and really doubted just how much money it should pour into the project, the honourable member for Parramatta at least had enough vision to know what could be achieved. It would be remiss of me if I did not pay that tribute here tonight because he did back the World Exposition to a very great degree. He made sure that Australia played a real part in it and that it was an Australian expo, not just a Queensland expo.

The city of Brisbane will never be the same. It has certainly come of age as a result of Expo. The people in the Queensland Government and in the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation who knew what the real benefits of World Expo 88 were going to be are already starting to see the fruits of their labours. There has been an incredible increase in the number of airline flights by international carriers coming into Queensland. It is true that those flights have been to look after the crowds for World Expo, but the advance bookings for next year are at record levels. Hotels in Brisbane are reporting 80 per cent occupancy rates way after Christmas, with record advance bookings for next year. The contribution that those thousands of people have made was a very good investment in the future of Australian tourism, it was a very good investment in making sure that Australia was well and truly on the world map and it was a magnificent celebration of Australia's bicentenary.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I can recall, the only claim to fame of the honourable member for Adelaide is that, during the by-election for the electorate of Adelaide, he came up with a whole series of outrageous claims. One claim was that while doorknocking he was told by a mother that her child was offered drugs at one of the high schools in the electorate of Adelaide. When the police went to the honourable member and asked him to substantiate the claims, he had no evidence. The reason I rise tonight is to draw to the House's attention something which I think is quite undesirable and something which could perhaps end up increasing the numbers of young people taking up the very bad habit of smoking. By holding up what I have in my hand, Mr Deputy Speaker, you might think I am breaking the Standing Orders by bringing a lighted cigarette into the chamber. If I were to put this toy to my mouth you would perhaps think that I was smoking in the House of Representatives chamber. In fact, I am not doing that. This is something called a puff cigarette which was drawn to my attention by one of my elderly constituents who was quite outraged that these toys were being sold in toy stores in my electorate. These puff cigarettes-I quote from the label-are not recommended for children under the age of eight years. It reflects poorly on any store in my electorate or anywhere else in Australia to be promoting a toy such as this for sale to young children. It would simply encourage them to take up the evil habit of smoking at some later stage in their life. I am sure that the fact that they are made in Taiwan does not reflect on the quality of the toy but it is something which should be discouraged.

I also draw to the attention of the House a booklet which was recently circulated to most honourable members. It was written by Michelle Cross from Wagga High School and it is entitled The power of the tobacco industry and the effects of cigarette smoking on adolescents. In a letter, Michelle Cross makes two very valid points: tobacco companies do have incredible influence and power over government, media, and hence individuals; and smoking is addictive and has damaging effects on life and this makes it a social problem of drug abuse. She say that adolescents take up smoking despite its effect on their health, which poses a question about their identity. She asks: Why do adolescents need to smoke? It is quite important that we do everything we can to make sure that young people do not think that smoking makes one look macho or manly. The promotion of these puff cigarette toys in stores in my electorate or anywhere else in Australia should be totally condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, the Australian electorate was treated to the almost hilarious but certainly unedifying sight of a government in crisis calling in each and every one of its Ministers to discuss strategy for the next election. If it were not so serious for the welfare of all Australians, it would be quite humorous that a government in such disarray felt it necessary to call in each and every Minister to try to map out some sense of unity and to formulate a sense of common purpose leading up to the next election. Mr Acting Speaker, no doubt you know as well as anyone else that that election is likely to be held towards the end of next year.

SPEECH.PARA: If only one could have been a fly on the wall. One could just imagine the relations with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), so aptly described as a lame duck leader following the hatchet job done on him by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) when he was Acting Treasurer. Perhaps seated on the other side of the lame duck and the ambitious Minister for Employment, Education and Training was the Treasurer (Mr Keating), coveting the position of the Prime Minister.

We understand that the Government won endorsement from that Ministry as to its economic policy. Mr Acting Speaker, you must call into question that Ministry's political judgment if it in any way reflects its economic judgment. How can a government be confident that the bases of its economic policy are in place when we have an inflation rate of some 7.3 per cent and the Budget estimate was 4.5 per cent? How can we have any confidence in a Ministry that agrees with a current account deficit for this financial year to date of $3.8 billion, being 40 per cent of the year's estimate of $9.5 billion? In 25 per cent of the time we have reached 40 per cent of the Government's estimate of the current account deficit. It means that over the next nine months there will have to be a current account deficit of only $620m each month-simply an unachievable goal for the Government.

Election fever is in the air. The Government seems to believe it has everything nicely and firmly in place. We are also told, by way of press reports and a somewhat curtailed press conference given by the Prime Minister, that the Government will now target the aged and the problems of housing and, if a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald is to be believed, it will also turn its mind towards science funding.

In the time remaining to me let me concentrate on the issue of science funding. All I can say is that if the Government is once again raising the hopes of the science community throughout Australia, just to dash them, as it has done so often in the past, it will pay a very heavy price at the next Federal election. The simple fact is, as so many Government members would know, clever, normally apolitical scientists are mobilising and turning their full fury against this Government with quite devastating electoral effects. It is not before time that the Government is now considering an increase in funding to science. But do not let people get their hopes up; there are certainly no guarantees on this Government's past record on science that it will come good, nor should the aged, although suffering from the housing crisis, put too much faith in yesterday's political decisions. The Government is very good at covering over problems-the band-aid approach. It will use every figure and every trick to con the people. It is very cunning and there is no doubt that it will try to pull the wool over people's eyes.

In last night's Melbourne Herald there was a very interesting report by Susan Peak, the science reporter, which showed that very valuable research, headed by Dr Leo Clarebrough, a Melbourne Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientist, would not have been undertaken except for the fact that the State Government came to the rescue. Funds of $1.2m were needed for a special microscope, called a Phillips CM-30 electron microscope. The Federal Government would not have contributed any funding except for the fact that the Cain Government contributed the lion's share. It gave $700,000 and the Hawke Government gave $500,000. The article states that according to scientists the research which they say is essential to the knowledge they will need to have by the year 2000 would not have gone ahead if it were not for the State Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May 1988 (Hansard, page 2673) Mr Lloyd asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Why has the Government allowed a 40 per cent duty to be applied to imported high quality lightweight woollen fabrics made from Australian wools, even though Australia's manufacturing industry does not have the capacity to produce this fabric in any quantity? Why was wool the only fabric excluded from by-law entry, its duty thus being increased from 2 per cent to 40 per cent under the guise of harmonisation? What is the sense of the wool industry developing new products like these and spending millions of woolgrower and government money on promoting them when the Australian Government prices them beyond the reach of the consumer?
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy referred the question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

The change in duty to which the Honourable Member refers is a result of the Government's new assistance arrangements for Australia's textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The new TCF arrangements embody substantial reform particularly in the area of tariffs and policy by-laws as the previous arrangements were very complex and had an adverse effect on users.

The change in duty for lightweight wool fabrics came about from the reform of the policy by-laws. Wool has not been singled out in these reforms. The number of policy by-laws has been reduced from 51 to 13 and their coverage was reduced for wool, cotton and synthetic fabrics. In addition there has been various other fabrics which have been affected by the new arrangements.

The reforms treat competing goods at comparable rates of duty at a series of duty rate plateaus. It was very important that like goods should attract a similar rate of duty regardless of weight differentials or end-use requirements in order to reduce the incidence of tariff induced substitution.

I appreciate that a 40 per cent tariff, which incidentally is being reduced to 35 per cent following the May Economic Statement, may cause some problems in areas such as the ``cool wool'' program. However, I understand that cool wool covers a wider range of fabrics than the by-law provision in question.

I should note that the question on whether Australia's manufacturing industry had the capacity to produce the goods in quantity was not a major consideration. Nevertheless, I understand lightweight wool fabrics are already produced in Australia and several major international wool textile companies are already exploring the feasibility of producing lightweight wool fabrics in Australia. These investigations are not dependent on tariff assistance as most of the production would be exported.

The tariff change to which you refer may have helped focus their attention on locating such activity in Australia and has had the effect of reinforcing the Government's promotion of adding value to wool. Contrary to the view of some wool growing interests, the local industry considers that there are significant prospects for more value added production of wool fabrics in the future.

Given that there are differences in views between wool growing interests and textile producers, I have asked the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to convene a meeting of the major interested parties to discuss the lightweight wool issue and to report back to me on the outcome of those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

(8) What is the estimated total cost of the inquiry, including the publication of the final report, associated papers and consultants' documents.

(11) Were representatives of the news media in attendance at the hearings; if not, were resumes of submissions presented at the hearings released by the committee to the news media.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Committee was not requested to rewrite any aspect of its report. By agreement, the deadline for submission of the report was extended to give the Committee more time to complete the report. The additional time was used for normal editing and checking of background material.

(2) Establishment of the inquiry followed an initiative contained in the ALP Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Policy, launched by the Hon RJL Hawke AC MP on 18 June 1987, to produce a Green Paper on Immigration.
(3) The terms of reference for the inquiry were decided by the then Minister for Immigration on the advice of his Department and in consultation with other Ministers.
(4) The decision on Committee membership was taken by the Government on the basis of wide ranging advice incorporating the views of officials and interested bodies.
(6) Although all the Committee had full-time work commitments throughout the period of the inquiry, they devoted substantial time to Committee work.

(7) Consistent with recent reforms freeing up administrative expenses, records of expenditure to the level sought are not maintained. However, the attached table dissects expenditure incurred by the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies (CAAIP) on the basis of recorded information. In respect of parts (e) (i) and (e) (ii), estimates of direct ``back-up'' costs incurred by my Department have been included in the attached table as have secretarial expenses. (8) The total identified cost of CAAIP was $742,000 in 1987-88 and $25,000 in 1988-89. Please see the information provided at question (7) for details.

(9) The Committee did not take formal evidence at any stage but consulted with 587 individuals and representatives of organisations. Notes of those consultations were taken and copied to those consulted. Consultations and workshops on possible recommendations proceeded throughout the Committee's work, both before and after the deadline for receiving written submissions, as is normal practice.
(10) The deadline for written submissions was extended to 31 January 1988 following Committee discussions with the then Minister.

(11) All the Committee's consultations and submissions made to the Committee were regarded by the Committee as public once its work was concluded unless submitted in confidence and received by the Committee on that basis. Some of the consultations were attended by media representatives. As is the normal practice under Freedom of Information legislation, submissions were regarded as working documents and not for release until the Committee's work was concluded.

(12) and( 13) Records of the consultations held in Adelaide on 19 November 1987 do not indicate that such a written submission was presented. Discussions with State Government agencies (Ethnic Affairs Commission, Department of State Development, Department of Environment and Planning, Office of Employment and Training and Premier's Department) touched on the capital cost of residential development on the fringe of the metropolitan area.

(14) The Government is undertaking a wide-ranging examination of the Committee's proposals including advice from a range of portfolio and community interests concerned and affected by immigration policies. The Government's National Population Council has also been asked to develop further a number of important matters raised by CAAIP. As the then Minister foreshadowed to Parliament on 3 June 1988, a statement on the main policy issues will be made in the Parliament in the Budget Sittings.
